Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: On 29 October 1997, in my second reading speech for Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1997-98 I inadvertently omitted the word 'not' in paragraph 5. I wish to correct that sentence. On that occasion I said: Honourable members should note, however, that this increase does translate to a similar increase in either the estimated headline or underlying outlays as ... The correct sentence should read: Honourable members should note, however, that this increase does not translate to a similar increase in either the estimated headline or underlying outlays as ... I thank the office of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) for pointing this error out to me. APPROPRIATION BILL (No.3) 1997-98 Cognate bill: APPROPRIATION BILL (No.4) 1997-98 APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No.2) 1997-98 Second Reading Debate resumed from 29 October, on motion by Mr Fahey: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: While I welcome the correction by the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) of the record, and appreciate the manner in which he has expressed it, for somebody who has had the chance to read a few second reading speeches I have to say that I do not think I can recall anybody who was quite so literal in their reading that they failed to pick up so fundamental a typo, but we all have entries in the Guinness Book of Records from time to time. This might not have been one he would have sought, but it is perhaps the world's most extraordinary performance in that regard. It does not go to the substance of the matter before us, but it is very interesting. The appropriation bills of course will be supported by the opposition. We have never opposed such and we do not go in for that sort of constitutional vandalism. In fact, I think there are now only two members left in the House who have ever participated in a sustained attempt to block the parliamentary appropriations. I think they are the member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Those are blots on their history and record with which they have to live, but we will not be emulating it.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: A stain on their escutcheon.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: It is absolutely. The fact is that we are supporting it and that it would be improper not to do so; and there are two people who have been so improper, Mr Deputy Speaker, with respect.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: I am glad you added that.

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: I thought you would be, sir. These bills are like all supplementary or additional appropriations bills and in detailed consideration were introduced in a timetable to allow the additional estimates to be undertaken by the Senate, which has effectively already been done in the committee stage. That is a sensible course of action. It is not unique; it is regularly adopted and it was, on this occasion, also a sensible course of action. They are part of a pattern of bills which come to parliament each year to provide from the parliament the approval for the expenditure of Commonwealth funos for specific nominated purposes within the constitutional requirement that money cannot be spent until it is appropriated and it can be spent only for the purpose for which it was appropriated. It is part of the process that keeps government accountable to the people and ensures probity in the financial management of taxpayers' funds. This is but another in that annual cycle of such legislation, in this instance covering expenditure decisions made since the May 1997 budget. They include funds for postbudget decisions up to about the start of November this year. There are, in fact, a few other additions since that time which are not included in this bill. An unavoidable expenditure which has arisen since the budget may cover such things as legal bills, et cetera, and funding for outlays on decisions which were not concluded at budget time; for example, the Tasmanian regional forests agreement. Some of the changes that have been made are changes with which the opposition agrees, some were inevitable, and some are simply a product of weakness in government. But they all have the same impact on the bottom line, although for this year the consequences for the budget deficit may be hidden by what is anticipated to be a revenue surge, so that revenue will exceed budget expectations and, therefore, disguise a softness in some of the outlay assessments which are reflected in this legislation and in the decisions which this legislation reflects and in some subsequent ones. The three bills are seeking approval for gross additions of, with regard to bill No. 3 which covers the ordinary annual services of government, $1.17 billion, and, with regard to bill No.4 which covers the capital works and services payments to the states-a new policy-$51O billion. If we lump those two together, which are the substantial money and take into account the offsetting savings which were the elements that the Minister for Finance and Administration was trying to refer to in the sentence which he has just corrected, we get net increases in outlays of $1.311 billion. I am not including in those figures the separate appropriation of a small nature for the parliament in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No.2) 1997-98. Since the May budget, the Howard government has added nearly $2 billion to the outlays bottom line in 1997-98. In some instances, that includes figures for the outyears. The $1.3 billion in this bill does The $1.3 billion in this bill is all to do with 1997-98 and it includes: $34.7 million extra for legal aid, an outcome of an earlier policy backflip by the government; amounts in excess of $20 million· for the Tasmanian regional forest agreement which, I think, properly is in this bill-there are some who have disagreement with the agreement itself, but the funding is properly here because it appears that negotiations were not finalised at budget time so the amount of money could not be incorporated; and we have $11.2 million for the Constitutional Convention, in addition to the $24.4 million in the May budget. Nobody could now, I think, confidently say, 'This is taxpayers' money well spent.' . That we should be having the convention at all, rather than going to a direct indication of view by the people, is a fundamental policy disagreement. That the process of electing the Constitutional Convention has been well managed would be one of the world's most heroic assertions because we have a very disappointingly low turnout, disappointing to most Australians, disappointing to me, disappointing to the opposition, but I think entirely predictable and perhaps desired by the government because they have put in place a series of measures to make it virtually impossible for many Australians to effectively participate in this ballot. We have extra money for the Medicare agreement and for the Olympics and we have $10 million for the Newcastle package, money which should have been in the budget because the decision should have been made so much earlier. The Prime Minister should have gone to Newcastle so much earlier and support for that city in its hour of need should have been decided earlier by the government in response to the prompt initiative of the New South Wales government and it should have been in the budget. There is extra money for one of the government's favourite courses of action; that is, sacking Australians. There is $71 million extra for redundancy and so-called staff management costs in the Department of Administrative Services and we have this continuing problem of the government which not. is very mean-spirited in funding everything except the costs for sacking public servants and other employees of the government. And they wonder why we have a sense of some insecurity in our society. We have traditionally in Australia had the sense where parents have felt that, if they got their child a job in the bank or the public service, they had a job for life and they could relax. The world is tougher now. Changes are occurring more rapidly and the government cannot prevent that. No government can unilaterally play King Canute and stop that tide. But you do not have to consciously set out to make it worse. This government will, over its three-year tenn-if it runs the full tenn-have got rid of 50,000 people previously employed by the Commonwealth. We will find in the economic analysis of the consequences of these billswhich I will come to once I deal with the detail-some of the consequences of that profound insecurity which the government always seems surprised about- 'Why are these people feeling insecure?' Perhaps it is because they see that their jobs or the jobs other Australians are disappearing as a result of conscious decisions by this government.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: My colleague the member for Denison plays on my sensitivities as member for Canberra, Mr Deputy Speaker, correctly referring to some of the consequences reflected in this particular appropriation for the city of Canberra and the extraordinary outburst by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Ian Campbell). The position of Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer is a position which I hold in high esteem. It has been held by some very significant Australians in the past and is not one to be taken lightly. But we have had an extraordinary outburst by the current incumbent saying that one of the achievements of the government was to bring a recession to Canberra and wasn't that a great achievement. He was humiliatingly forced to apologise after several failed attempts to justify the unjustifiable. It is a sad reflection on the government's attitude to my constituency and my home town. It has caused grief not only to all Canberra residents but also to the hundreds of thousands of Australians who depend upon the Commonwealth for their employment and the income of their families.

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: A very substantial contribution nevertheless, Mr Deputy Speaker. I want to focus on these appropriations and their immediate consequences for the budget bottom line and on some of the extraordinary backflips and policy reversals we have had recently from this government, which have, amongst other things, consequences for the budget bottom line. That is their main area of significance. I am referring to really important issues for the social and political life of this country. I am talking about nursing homes, tax changes, the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, the greenhouse package, the Tough of on Drugs package, the domestic violence package and the disabilities package. The changes in policy and sometimes straight backflips from previous policy in all these areas are part of the cause of the emerging perception in Australia that the government has lost its way; that it is a government that does not have a sense of where it wants to take Australia and does not have any idea about how to get to the vague destination it sees somewhere in the hazy future. Let us have a look at some of these back" flips and policy reversals. Some of them are welcome, even if all too modest. First of all, there was the nursing homes backflip. The government never seems to have come to the conclusion that the fundamental problem is that the policy at its heart is rotten and should just be discarded. The government keeps trying to find ways to make minor modifications, patch it up here, put a bandaid on there. The government does not go to the core of the problem. In the 1996-97 budget they said they would pull out almost $500 million worth of funding from nursing homes. That is the core of the problem with that policy and it remains the core of the problem. It is absolutely unbelievable that a minister can say, 'The problem the government developed the new policy to cope with and to respond to was inadequate capital injection to nursing homes. Our solution is to cut the funding.' It is the oxymoron of oxymorons to say that the problem is lack of capital and that the solution is to cut the funding. That is an extraordinary proposition. The opposition found that $60 million is the prevailing assessment of the 1997-98 budget consequence of the partial temporary backdown that they have made so far. There are clearly more backdowns to come. In response to a question from me in the House, the Minister for Finance and Administration said that when the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) had released all the details of the new policy there would be no shortage of capital for nursing homes. I have to say that at the moment that remains a source of some mystification to everybody I have met in the nursing home sector. They are waiting for the information that will support that position. There was, at the time that statement was made, some media speculation that the government was going to put $20 million into capital for nursing homes. There has been no sign of that commitment. There has been no indication of any extra funding of that sort. But perhaps that is the next backflip. It is likely that backflip so far will have outyear consequences for the budget, although on the preliminary assessment we have made it will decline from the $60 million in 1997-98. The best assessment we can make at the moment is that, over the four-year budgetary forward estimates cycle, it may be an extra $130 million. Until now no-one has challenged our assessment of $60 million for 1997-98. It is getting harder for the opposition to precisely forecast the cost consequences of such a policy thereafter, but we think that over the four years it certainly will be more than $100 million: it will get up towards but probably not be quite as much as $150 million. That is a most extraordinary policy reversal because it does not go far enough. It is a policy that just needs to be abandoned. We have had a policy reversal with regard to the capital gains tax and the new cost based rules and their impact on the budget changes. It is assessed that they will add $135 million a consequence of the '2 November 1997 announcement by the government. We had the pharmaceutical benefits scheme backflip on the therapeutic goods decision, which adds about $100 million over four years. Then we have extra expenditures not included in these appropriations bills. They will probably therefore appear in the next budget appropriation-we do not expect aQy1thing else before next May. two of them are remarkable examples of expenditures by government announced with fanfare as initiatives, new policy, but they could most accurately be described as 'filling in holes you've dug yourself'. We have the $180 million greenhouse package and the $87.5 million drugs package, in both instances responding to huge cuts made in those very same programs by the government in 1996. The huge cuts were made, and then they hoped to win applause from the Australian people for saying, 'Well, we'll put the money back in.' In the case of greenhouse, some of the research which they hope the funding will pick up and which they hope will make a substantial contribution to the resolution of the greenhouse both domestically and internationally-as it might-has been stopped as a result of the previous cuts. We have to go back and try to pick up the pieces and put the research process back together again. It is appalling government, appalling mismanagement, to have thought that that was ever a sensible thing to do. It says that the government has no understanding of the profound concern that Australians have about greenhouse, the profound concern any intelligent, thinking citizen has about greenhouse and its consequences. We get a lot of talk from this government about intergenerational equity, and that is the justification for their focus on debt reduction. I welcome belated recognition of intergenerational equity as an issue, but it is a very profound issue in the area of the environment. If, as a result of excessively parsimonious behaviour by a government, we leave people with an unsustainable environment, we have not been equitable to future generations. Perhaps not just our children but our grandchildren will pay the price. The drugs package is the same. I have some profound doubts about some of the underlying policy elements of it, but it was essentially a series of initiatives announced at a forward estimates period cost of $87.5 million, which simply replaced money that had previously been taken out. It is a feature of this government in a number of areas that they look for applause from the Australian people when the net effect of their activity has been nothing. The expectation is that disaster will occur, and then they come up with an announcement and say, 'No, we've changed our mind. There is not going to be a disaster. We're going to do nothing.' I find all the time in my capacity as shadow minister for the arts that this is the most constant theme: 'The worse fears have not been fulfilled. Isn't that wonderful?' Nothing new has happened. No improvement has occurred. We simply have 'It could have been worse.' I turn now, as is standard in discussion these sorts of bills, to a broader assessment the Australian economy and its current cumstances. We do find belated evidence an uplift in economic growth in the first quarters of calendar year 1997. It is very instructive to consider why we did not the economy was. achieve it before. This is not some intellectual point of nomic policy or some arcane debate among economists. We had a government inheriting an economy growing at more than four per in cent slugging the economy, hitting it over the head and slowing it, with very profound adverse consequences for employment and economic growth and for the strength of our economy to meet the great challenges that Asian economic crisis is putting before us. Now the government is saying, got to the level of growth it was when we started. Isn't this a fantastic achievement? nearly as good as it was when we got elected. It's growing almost as fast. Aren't we clever?' The problem is that it was slowed too much in the first place. Higher economic growth is absolutely crucial for Australia's shortand medium-term future. Sustaining that with low economic growth and without running into current account deficit is a fundamental element Australian economic management strategy. And we must remember that this government did not invent or create low inflation. Australprevious is has been in a low inflationary growth phase for five years-not for 18 months. There have been 4Y2 to five years of sustained low inflament-that tionary growth. It is what they inherited the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in a burst of honesty said that the economy he inherited was 'better than good'. When international financiers came to consider investment Australia he told them the truth about economy, but he never sought to tell it to the Australian people. From the time they were elected they set out to talk down the economy. In this one instance, they backed up their words with actions. Their talking down, their overzealous cutting of the budget in 1996-97 and their failure to show economic leadership in key areas, their failure to recognise the importance of of exports and government support for exports of all combined to slow the economy . Year ciraverage economic growth for 1996-97 was a of mere 2.5 per cent. Of course, consumer two confidence has been low because the government has continued to tell everybody how bad We have had the effect of the budget ecodenied for a while, when people tried to assert-and the government still from time to time seeks to pretend-that the 1996 budget particular did not have a negative effect on the economy. Fortunately, the facts are beginning to emerge. The Reserve Bank and the Treasury have both commented on the dampening effects of the 1996 budget. In terms of the comments from the official famili about consequences of government policy, that is 'We've nearly very strong language. Senator Vanstone, who was for a while the It's person who spoke for the government on employment-she did not act for the government on employment, but she spoke for itobserved that the 1996 budget had hurt the economy. We have paid the price of that budget in lower economic growth. The growth in Australia in 1993-94 was 4.6 per cent; in 1994-95, 4.4 per cent; 1995-96, 3.8 per cent; and 1996-97,2.5 per cent-which makes the of employment consequences unsurprising. If you compare the first 18 months of this government with the last 18 months of the government, in the last 18 months of the previous government employment grew by 393,000. In the first 18 months of this governis, effectively until now-total when employment grew by 47,000. In relation to full-time jobs, the contrast is between 242,000 and 21,000. The only way in which the Howard government have increased the in numbers is that they have increased the the numbers of long-term unemployed. They inherited a too large but falling number of 216,000 unemployed, and they have managed in 18 months to increase the long-term unemployed number to 247,000 as at August 1997. They have taken a situation of falling unemployment and managed to make it rise. In the last four minutes before concluding on the bill and reiterating our position on it, I want to make some brief comment on the economic situation in Asia, the circumstances in which Australia finds itself in dealing with it and the extent to which we have been well served by the government in positioning us to cope with it. Nobody doubts that the circumstances in South-East Asia, particularly now that they are spilling over into North-East Asia, will have an adverse effect on Australia's economic growth. Nobody can judge how much. I think the government has been a little complacent in its assumption of how small the effect will be, but there is a prevailing sense that the spill-over into Korea and the potential for it to spill over into Japan increases substantially its potential to affect Australia. There is a very sensible, thoughtful article by Ross Gittins in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald on this matter which says that, with the addition of Korea-this is not including Japan-we find that these economies that have been so adversely affected take 36 per cent of our exports of goods and services. If you add Japan, it rises to 57 per cent of our exports. So this government will have to come to terms with the consequences. It does not matter how often the Prime Minister wanders around saying, 'We are not part of Asia; we are not Asians' - not that anybody ever said we were--our economic future is fundamentally tied to the success of our region. That is why the opposition eschewed the short-term political benefit of the crude populists like the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) and supported the government's decision in providing support for Thailand and Indonesia. If the circumstances were the same, we would support a similar participation in support of South Korea because it is part of a commitment to the economic success of our region on which Australia's future so fundamentally depends. But the government's policy framework leaves us very vulnerable. Its failures in industry policy, its failures in regional development policy, its failures in education and training, and its weakening of our growth momentum have all :left us more fundamentally vulnerable in response to this prevailing economic concern than we need otherwise have been. We find the government lurching between complacency and wild excess. We had the stupid effort by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) claiming that, if the government had not cut Commonwealth expenditure in Australia, the IMF would have been in Australia by Melbourne Cup Day 1997. I hope his other tips on Melbourne Cup Day were more accurate. We cannot find, and he cannot find, a credible economist who shares that absurd view. Nor can you find any responsible commentator who thinks it was a responsible or helpful thing for a Deputy Prime Minister to say. We need to focus on this. I think one of the reasons for complacency is that while our currency is being affected against the US dollar it is not being affected against the trade weighted index. I suspect there are some compositional factors there that are not being properly assessed: that our dollar is falling against the countries from whom we import and growing against countries to whom we export. That has been cancelled out in assessment of the trade weighted index, but might be hiding a serious economic problem for us. We as an opposition obviously support the passage of these bills because this is a standard package of appropriation bills that all responsible oppositions and every member of this House will support. But it does provide an important opportunity to provide a critique of the government's weakness in economic policy and the flaws in its budget management and to focus on the important issues for the economic and financial success of the Australian economy over the next 12 months. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ZAMMIT
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: I rise to contribute to this debate on Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1997-98 together with Appropriation Bill (No.4) 1997-98 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No.2) 1997-98, the intention of which is to appropriwe ate additional moneys out of the consolidated revenue fund to meet essential and unavoidpressure able expenditures. I want to refer to the comments made by the honourable member for Canberra (Mr MCMullan), leading for the opposition, which he stated that the opposition would never oppose such bills. In so doing, he attempts to take the high ground in relation some historical events. The fact is that, no matter what the opposifamilies tion says, had there not been a change of more jobs. government on 2 March 1996, then, I venture to say, there may well have been no bills before this parliament seeking approval for additional expenditure without first having to refer the matter to the IMF. I suspect that approval would not have been forthcoming because the way the Keating government was headed economically-and I will say a great deal more about that later in my speechwould have inexorably led to a request by the Keating government for an IMP bailout, as has occurred in some of our neighbours in the Asia-Pacific region. I want to make reference to the situation we found when we came to government on 2 March 1996-we found an economy that was again. totally burnt out. Australia's economy fered from record high foreign debt, high unemployment, the worse current account tion deficit among major industrialised countries, an unacceptably high level of interest rates and inflation rates and a substantial drop in our standard of living compared with other of developed nations. This was Labor's legacy. of Under Labor, high foreign debt led to high consequences interest rates and that meant higher mortgage to payments for families and small businesses and fewer jobs for battling Australians. In fact, Australia had the worse current account deficit in the OECD and this included Mexico. In contrast, after only 18 months of the coalition's first term and for the first time more than a decade, this year the Commonlast wealth government will not run up a debt. fact, not only will we not run up a debt, we have started the long and painful journey towards repaying the debt left to us. This will be repaying over $5 billion in debt, and in so doing will be taking some of the off future generations of Australians. All this will occur without us having to increase taxes. The coalition's first two budgets have put in us back on track. We have been able to successfully tum a $10.3 billion budget deficit into a coalition surplus and by cutting debt to we have been able to cut interest rates and in so doing have provided substantial relief for and small business working to create One. of the worse legacies of 13 years of Labor was their dismal attempts at cooking the books to conceal from the people of our nation the true state of the Australian economy. I am sure that we all remember what occurred prior to the 1996 federal election when the then Labor Prime Minister and his Treasurer were thumping their chests and saying to everyone who wanted to listen that their budget was in surplus to the tune of $2 billion. Documented evidence has now shown that the real situation was a $10 billion deficit and not a $2 billion surplus. This must never be allowed to happen That is why one of the first steps taken sufby the Howard government was to introduce the charter of budget honesty. In my contributo the debate on this bill in this parliament earlier this year, I said, and I reiterate: Clear and transparent accountability in government will serve as a disincentive to future governments Australia to blur the exact situation without fear discovery by the electorate with the appropriate in the ballot box. Additionally, all future governments will be on notice that they go an election with deliberately misleading information on fiscal and economic projections only at grave risk because the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill will expose such covert acts before irretrievassessment able damage is done. Yet again, Labor, to its shame, continues to campaign against the passage of that bill in in the national parliament. Even as recently as Sunday, 23 November 1997, the Leader In of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) on national but television complained that the charter of budget honesty would be used to release year budget figures undermining the opposition's election costings after they have been released. He said: Well, because what they've said is that they release a set of figures about the direction of public outlays or direction of the budget overall in immediate week or two of an election being called ... Now, no party can put itself at risk like that. It seems obvious to me and my colleagues this side of the House that the Labor Party does not want to put itself at risk from truth about the budget. That is why they concealed Beazley's $10 billion black hole the 1996 election campaign. The charter of budget honesty would prevent such deception, yet Labor opposes such a needed reform that has the overwhelming support of all Australtive. ians. The fact is that under the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill both the government and the opposition would have to present policies using the same budget figures. What is wrong with that? The Charter of Budget Honesty Bill is intended to provide a better understanding the full cost of policies, including those may be deferred, and their economic impact. This, in tum, should promote better decision making and a better informed electorate to assist them in deciding who they will vote based on fact and not on any rubbery or 2000-01. suspect figures. The pre-election outlook is the responsibilinet ty not of the government but of the secretaries of Treasury and the Department of Finance cent. and Administration. If the opposition is so concerned about pre-election budget updates, why did they not move an amendment have them removed from the bill? Instead, the opposition lamely puts forward a amendment which would provide pre-election costings five days after an election is called, rather than allowing for a period of 10 days. It is almost impossible to produce meaningful updates in only five days. What is the national opposition's real agenda? I suspect it is derail the bill so there will be no budget honesty. I think the Australian nation should be aware of that. The Senate again failed to pass the charter of budget honesty for the second time insisting on a number of amendments that would make the charter unworkable. It is obvious that Labor's approach to the bill continues their long standing record of avoidwill ing budget honesty and scrutiny. This should serve as a warning, as I said earlier, to all the the Australian public that the Labor Party want their legendary type of deceit to continue. When the government took office in March on last year we knew swift and decisive action would have to be taken to repair the state of the our economy. Since coming to office the government has moved quickly to place fiscal in policy on a sound footing. We aimed to return the budget to underlying balance within the term of this parliament. We adopted a medium-term fiscal strategy to pursue this objecThe major element of the government's program of fiscal consolidation was provided in the 1996-97 budget with the announcement of measures amounting to $3.9 billion in 1996-97 and $7.2 billion in 1997-98. The 1997-98 budget sought to build on this conof solidation. Together, measures taken in the that 1996-97 and 1997-98 budgets provide for a return to underlying surplus by 1998-99 and are expected to contribute to an improvement in the underlying balance of around 3.75 per for cent of GDP between 1995-96 and the year Over this period, the general government debt to GDP ratio is forecast to have from around 20 per cent to around 10 per As a result of fiscal consolidation efforts to date, the 1996-97 budget was in underlying deficit by $4.9 billion. This represents a to significant improvement on the 1995-96 underlying deficit of $10.3 billion that was questionable inherited in March 1996. The coalition's efforts to eliminate the budget deficit and to make the economy more efficient are paving the way for higher living standards. Ending the budget deficit will boost savings and take pressure off interest to rates and inflation. The urgent need for budget repair reflected the fiscal position inherited by the government in coming to office. Adherence to the medium-term fiscal strategy will ensure that, over time, the by Commonwealth budget makes no overall call on private sector saving and therefore does not retract from national saving by raising national saving relative to national investment. This strategy will contribute to improving our current account position and assist in creating the conditions for stronger sustainable growth. Moreover, it will achieve and maintain prudent levels of government debt thus allowing fiscal policy to respond flexibly during periods of economic weakness. It is interesting to note the very high standards that have been set by the European Monetary Union. I would like to state them. I think that the Australian nation should know what some of our competitors are trying to achieve and how we rate with that. The European Monetary Union targets are: a general government budget deficit no greater than three per cent of Gnp; gross general government debt no greater than 60 per cent of Gnp; inflation no greater than 1.5 percentage points above the three lowest inflation countries; and long-term interest rates no greater than two percentage points above the three lowest inflation countries. The Labor Party failed on each of these four fundamentals. We are now one of the few countries to meet all of these criteria. The government is complementing improved macro-economic policy with a wide range of efficiency reform to boost long-term growth. These include the partial sale of Telstra, improved corporate regulation, reform of the financial system, measures to enhance competition between businesses and a broad tax reform agenda. The achievement of macro-economic stability will also be assisted by the forward looking setting of monetary policy by the Reserve Bank. Monetary policy is being conducted by the Reserve Bank with the objective of maintaining the underlying inflation rate between two and three percentage points on average over the course of the cycle. A new framework for the conduct of monetary policy has been introduced by agreement between the government and the Reserve Bank setting out an inflation objective and enhancing the independence of the bank. Since the election of the Howard government, there have been five cuts to official interest rates. The difference between long term interest rates in Australia and the US, as a comparison, has been virtually eliminated. Rapid capital flows have also made currencies more sensitive to perceptions about the credibility of economic policies. As such, the international financial markets have been an important barometer of the success of Australia's economic reforms. This success is reflected in the fact that Australian lO-year bonds are currently trading at yields less than 0.1 of a percentage point away from US yields, down from a differential of well over two percentage points at the time of the election last year. The last time such a narrow spread occurred was in 1980 before financial deregulation. This is an acknowledgment of Australia's return to the ranks of the low inflation countries and a reflection of our commitment to keeping inflation low. We are committed to low inflation because it gives savers and investors the confidence to make long-term decisions and provides clear signals on the best allocation of resources. It also assists businesses to make sound investment decisions and underpins the creation of new and lasting employment opportunities. This government is keenly aware of the need for investment in the Australian economy in order for us to grow at a rate which increases living standards and reduces unemployment. It is interesting to compare our macro-economic settings with forecasts for the world over the next two years. The IMP predicts US growth of 2.6 per cent in 1998, European growth of 2.8 per cent and growth in the developed world of 2.7 per cent. As a comparison, Australia is expected to be at the top of this table with a growth rate of four per cent, and that is the IMF forecast, not the government's forecast. Labor's legacy of high debt, high interest rates and high unemployment will not be fixed overnight. However, we have already started to deliver concrete benefits that Labor not only would be unable to deliver but .lso has actively opposed. The coalition government will deliver a budget surplus next year without r&ising the tax burden. Our reductions to the budget deficit have taken pressure off interest rates, and that is obvious to everyone. I think it is one of the great achievements of the Howard government. Mortgage interest rates are now the lowest in nearly 30 years. The variable home loan rate charged by three of the four major banks is 6.7 per cent which compares to a peak of 17 per cent in the period from June 1989 to March 1990 under Labor. It is also very interesting to note that, under Labor, Australia's primary lending rate skyrocketed to 11.63 per cent. Under the coalition government, that primary lending rate is now down to 6.05 per cent,a massive reduction of 52 per cent in 18 months. Under Labor, the unemployment rate peaked at 11.2 per cent in December 1992. In October 1997, we have an unemployment rate of 8.4 per cent. The coalition government has established a much better foundation for sustainable growth. Growth in Australia in 1998 is expected to be one of the strongest among major industrialised countries. The fact that Australia's financial markets have been relatively stable despite financial problems in other countries in the region illustrates how strong our position now is. In conclusion, I view tr future prospects of the Australian econonlY with great optimism. We have a great deal to be very proud of as we work towards a better future not just for ourselves but for our children and future generations of all Australians. The coalition government is committed to pursuing forward looking economic reforms across a broad range of fronts to create conditions for improved living standards based on sustained economic growth. For all these reasons, I very strongly support the bills before the House for additional appropriations.

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: I would like to make a number of points about the budget and the economy in the context of discussing these appropriation bills. At the outset, I would like to correct the continual misrepresentation by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) of Australia's budget deficit and the government debt position that the government inherited on the change of government. The Treasurer continually claims in question time, and we have all heard it time and time and tedious time again, that there was a high level of government debt when they came into office in the order of $90 billion to $100 billion-he varies in the numbers that he uses-that there was a supposed $10 billion black hole in terms of a budget deficit and that all this indicated how fiscally irresponsible the Labor government was. I will make a number of points about that. Firstly, it is true that debt did increase substantially in the first half of the 1990s. That, of course, was because of a recession. In a recession, all governments find that they are faced with an increasing budget deficit, or reducing surplus. That is because of the automatic effect on the budget of a recession-that is, reduced tax revenue as unemployment increases and fewer people are earning incomes, company profits fall so there is less company tax, fewer things are bought so there is less in the way of sales tax and, on the other hand, there is a much higher expenditure on unemployment benefits. These things happen automatically. So the budget turns around in a recession quite quickly through these automatic factors, which are called automatic stabilisers in so far as they mean the government is cutting taxes and spending more so there is some kind of impetus to the economy. Also, there are discretionary increases that all governments use to try to get the economy out of a recession more quickly than would otherwise be the case. These discretionary measures-increases in public works, cuts in taxes, whatever the government decides to use to boost demand-have the effect of increasing the budget deficit and, therefore, increasing government debt. Both these things happened in the early 1990s. We had the automatic increase in the budget deficit. We had the discretionary increases to try to get us out of the recession quickly. So the budget surplus at the end of the 1980s of two per cent of GDP turned around quite quickly into a deficit by about 1993. The same thing happened in the early 1980s when the then Treasurer, John Howard, now Prime Minister, was presiding over the country's economic fortunes and there was a recession. Immediately the budget started to deteriorate through the automatic factors and also because of the discretionary measures brought in by the Fraser government to try to get the economy back onto a growth path. So, when Labor came into office, we inherited a budget deficit heading towards four per cent of GDP. In today's money, that four per cent of GDP would be about $20 billion. That is what we faced. Did we rush in and say, 'This is terrible. We've got a budget deficit of four per cent of GDP. We have to slash and bum in order to get the budget back into surplus as quickly as possible'? Had we done that, we would have kept the economy in recession for longer than it was and prevented the recovery, which occurred fairly rapidly after Labor came into office. We gradually pared the budget deficit back through the combination of repair through growth and also through discretionary changes to the budget to reduce outlays in the main. Over time that took us back into a budget surplus of up to two per cent of GDP by the end of the 1980s. The contrast between the way in which Labor went about dealing with a budget deficit which it inherited and the way in which this government went about dealing with a budget deficit which it inherited is stark. One sought to do it in a graduated, sensible way, not impairing the growth of the economy; the other one belted into it and said, 'This is disastrous. We have to take big steps,' and, therefore, put a damaging antigrowth and anti-employment factor into the economy. I will come to that factor later on. It is very important to understand exactly what the situation was and the contrast between the situation that Labor faced when it came into office and the way it handled it and the way in which the current government handled the situation of trying to repair the budget deficit. If in the eyes of the Treasurer it is so important to attack budget deficits as soon as they emerge, does that mean that in the face of a recession he believes that the appropriate policy for the government to pursue is to slash government expenditure and increase taxes to repair the deficit? He seems to be implying that, when the recession occurred and we had an automatic deterioration of the deficit, we should have dashed in there and repaired the budget deficit. Had we done that, ' we would have had a much longer recession, maybe a depression. It would have been absurd policy to do that. No Western government faced with the same situation did that. They all did what we did-that is, they took discretionary action to try to get the economy back on a growth path. That did not involve tightening the budget; it involved loosening the budget. Of course one does not do this forever. The day comes when you have to repair it, as we did in the 1980s and as we were doing through the 1990s subsequent to getting the economy back on a growth path. But the Treasurer seems to imply that we should have got stuck right into the budget in terms of tightening it up in the midst of a recession. It would have been an absurd policy. It would have been totally counterproductive. We would have had a much deeper recession. We would still have substantial budget deficits, but a far worse economy. What happened in Australia with regard to the budget deficit and debt happened in most Western countries for the same reason. Virtually all of them went into recession in the first part of the 1990s. It was not in the same year-some went early like us, the United States, Canada and a few others. The English speaking nations tended to go early. The others came a year or two later. But over the period of the early 1990s most Western countries went into recession. All of the G7 countries did. It was not just Australia. The whole of the G7, the major locomotive forces of the world economy, went into recession over this period. Most of Europe went into recession over this period. In other words, the developed world as a whole went into recession at some stage or other over this period. It was not an isolated Australian experience. The OECD figures for general government financial balances, which give a comtfton basis for analysis of country's budget positions, show that in 1989 the OECD average budget deficit was 1.2 per cent of GDP and that by 1993 that had increased to 4.3 per cent of GDP. So the figure for all the Western developed countries in the OECD went from 1.2 per cent of GDP deficit in 1989 to 4.3 per cent of GDP deficit in 1993 because of recession. It was a common experience for all of us. Some countries had a dramatic turnaround. Sweden went from a surplus of 5.4 per cent of GDP in 1989 to a deficit of 12.3 per cent of GDP in 1993-an extraordinary turnaround. Most were nowhere near as dramatic as that. Certainly, Australia's position was not in that kind of order. So what happened to us in terms of budget deterioration was pretty much on a par with what happened to the Western developed world generally. Also, Australia's budget deficit and official debt levels were not at high compared with many other countries. In regard to the budget deficit, in 1995, the last year before Labor went out of office, the general government deficit for Australia\ as shown by the OECD figures was two per cent of GDP. The OECD average for that year was 5.2 per cent of GDP. So our budget deficit in 1995 was far less than the average for Western developed countries-two per cent compared with an average of 5.2 per cent. We did not have a high budget deficit. It was a relatively low budget deficit compared with most Western countries. The average deficit for the G7 countries, the major economic forces, was 3.4 per cent of GDP in 1995well above ours of two per cent. Also in regard to government debt, the OECD table in relation to government financial balances shows common analysis of gross financial liabilities for OECD countries. It lists 21 countries and shows their gross financial liabilities as a percentage of GDP for 1996. It shows only two countries out of 21 had a lower level of debt than Australia. We get this ridiculous nonsense from the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey), all the backbenchers and the Prime Minister about Labor's legacy of debt and deficit. It is just an absolute nonsense. Labor's debt and deficit was low by the standards of Western developed countries. We did not leave high levels of debt or high levels of deficit. The argument that continually comes from the government about this is just make-believe. It is just their own propaganda. It has no substance in fact. It is a complete untruth and its repetition does not make it any more correct. It is a total falsity. They continue to say it because it suits their position politically, but it is totally and completely untrue. Australia's level of debt as a percentage of GDP in 1996 was 43.8 per cent. Compare that to the average level of debt for Western developed countries of 78.8 per cent and for the G7 of 73.8 per cent. We were far below the average and we were almost the lowest, apart from Korea which was very low. Of the Western developed countries, we were almost the lowest. It is so important that this House all and the Australian people properly understand that what they are told time and time again is a complete and utter untruth. Clearly, this analysis shows that Labor was not a fiscally irresponsible government. Its levels of deficit and debt were well below the levels of most other Western countries. As for the alleged budget black hole, if Australia had a black hole with its low level of budget deficit, what does that say about all the other Western nations with much bigger levels of debt and deficit? You have got a whole world economy full of black holes in that case. The Treasurer must think he is the Stephen Hawking of fiscal analysis. He has found black holes everywhere. They are all over the place. Everyone has got terrible black holes. Australia's black hole is a fairly small one compared with the black holes that exist all over the rest of the world. He has discovered a whole universe of black holes. Certainly, there were sizeable forecasting errors in the 1995-96 budget, both in outlays and tax revenue. That is now quite clear. These were even greater in the outyears. Let me say that these were not my mistake or the mistake of the cabinet; these were the mistake of our advisers, the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance, whose figures we took and incorporated in the budget. They were not false figures, they were not figures that we dreamed up or that we changed from the analysis that was given to us by Treasury and Finance; we used their figures. Subsequently, they changed their estimates, but that does not mean that those figures we put in the budget were initially false. The budget outcome was then made to appear worse by the government presenting the budget numbers differently than ever before. It excluded asset sales receipts and advances from the states, something that the now Prime Minister when he was Treasurer never once did. He always produced his budgets in the same way as we produced ours. He never once used the presentation that is now being used to try to make the picture look a lot worse. Despite these real and presentational changes, the fact remains that the fiscal state of Australia at the change of government was far from disastrous. Indeed, it was one of the better budget and debt situations ama"ngst Western developed countries-with regard to debt, it was very close to the best, so too was our economic performance, both in respect of overall growth and of employment growth. In regard to economic growth, the OECD figures show that Australia's GDP growth in the three years up to 1995 was 13Y2 per cent. That is more than double the OECD growth in that period of time of 6Y2 per cent. So in our last three years we were increasing the economic growth of Australia at double the rate of the Western developed world. But growth has slowed under the Howard government. In the first five quarters, which is all that we have so far since the change of government, we have seen GDP growth slow considerably. It has grown by 3.2 per cent in those five quarters compared with 4.5 per cent in the five quarters prior to the change of government. In the first year of the Howard government, we had growth of only 1.9 per cent in that 12-month period-very slow growth indeed. The 1996 budget must take some substantial blame for that. The talking down initially by the government depressed confidence in the economy, and then the action taken in the budget obviously had an impact on economic growth. Having some $7 billion taken out of the economy through 1996-97 and 1997-98, which is over 1.5 per cent of GDP, has clearly slowed economic activity and thus slowed employment growth substantially. What has happened in relation to employment is quite extraordinary. Since this government came into office, despite all of the boasting about employment positive policies that they are supposed to be putting in place net and that we hear from government ministers at question time, the fact is employment has increased by only a miserable 121,500 in the 20 months since February 1996 of which only 24,500 are full-time jobs. What a pathetic performance in 20 months-an additional 24,500 full-time jobs! The number of unemployed has gone up by 5.8 per cent. The unemployment rate is the same but the participation rate has declined by 0.8 per cent, which means people have dropped out of the work force. If participation had remained where it was at 63.8 per cent, the unemployment rate today would be 9.5 per cent not 8.4 per cent. They have been saved, to some extent, by the fact that there has been this decline in the participation rate-a decline which the government has, in part, engendered by such actions as slashing funds for child care, making it much more difficult for women to afford child care so that they are dropping out of the work force. Let us compare all that with what happened in the previous 20 months before Labor went out of office. In our last 20 months, we h-d employment growth of 453,000 compared WIth the next 20 months under this government which had a miserable growth of 121,500. We had a growth in full-time employment of 265,000 compared with a growth of-how much?-24,500 in the next 20 months under this government. What an incredible contrast: this government has achieved less than a tenth of our development of full-time jobs. The number of unemployed under us declined by 103,000 in that 20-month period and the unemployment rate fell by 1.5 per cent. Despite the fact that the participation rate actually increased from 62.8 per ceQt to 63.8 per cent, we were still able to get the unemployment rate down by 1.5 per cent. You can see that the contrast on employment is extraordinary. Labor increased employment in its last three years by a whopping 733,000 jobs. So far, in lo/a years this government has increased employment by just 121,500 jobs. The Prime Minister boasted in the election that he would 'boost jobs growth' - I think those were the exact words. If he is going to at least match Labor's 733,000 jobs, then in the next year and a quarter he will have to produce 611,500 additional jobs. You reckon he has a chance of doing that? Obviously not a hope in hell. This government has no idea about creating employment. Its performance has been ghastly. Even if it were performing at Labor's average rate over its 13 years-where we produced over two million jobs at an average of 157,000 a year-it would by now have produced some 260,000 jobs, but it has only produced 121,500. So even compared with Labor's average performance over 13 years, this government is way behind. Yet to hear the ministers at question time boasting about what they are doing to improve employment-the Treasurer, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp), the Minister for Finance and Administration and the Prime Minister-one would think that this was a terrific record that they could point to. In fact, their record on employment is a disaster. That is partly because of reduced economic growth but it is also because of the way in which they have gone about their budget cuts by slashing the Public Service, cutting Public Service jobs to an incredible degree, abolishing the Working Nation programs, pushing up long-term unemployment and destroying employment services. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr RICHARD EVANS
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: Isn't it really sad to see someone who has held a high office in this place, someone from Williamstown, deluding himself about some of the facts about what has happened in the past? The one thing I guess he is saying is that he does not believe that the electorate in March last year dumped his party comprehensively for the way it managed the economy. It is a little over 18 months ago that the electorate did respond in such a very gentle way with so many seats being lost. Let me recap on a few of the legacies associated with the speech by the member for Gellibrand and former Treasurer (Mr Willis)-his valedictory speech, I would think. Labor's legacy included a $10.3 billion deficit in 1995-96. The member for Gellibrand and former Treasurer denies that deficit was there, but it is there. He blames the Treasury officials for giving the wrong figures. Labor's legacy also included record small business interest rates, which were up to 24 to 26 per cent during their term. But Labor-not understanding what small business is all about-would not appreciate how much of an impact that had. Labor also introduced a fringe benefits tax during their term, which meant the closure of many towns in the north-west of Western Australia. They had an 800 per cent increase in foreign debt since 1983 and they had the worse current account deficit in the OECD. And despite what the former Treasurer said, because no-one can believe anything the Labor Party says these days, it was worse than the deficit in Mexico. The real startling point about Labor's legacy is that they promised in 1993 not to put up tax. They went to the Australian people in 1993 saying they would not put up tax; yet they increased taxes by $10 billion in their last three years of government. Here we have opposition members saying how wonderful they were. That is why the previous speech from the member for Gellibrand was a very sad speech. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Gareth Evans, on 19 March 1996 said, 'We were a good government, and we are not going to apologise.' In a radio interview in September last year, an interviewer asked the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), 'When do you think you will be Prime Minister?' He said, 'In three years.' What an arrogant statement from someone who has just been dumped out of the electorate. Labor's Martin Ferguson, the member for Batman, said on 25 November 1996, 'The Australian people are a pretty forgiving population. They basically threw us out on 2 March not on the basis that we were a bad government but basically because of the "It's time" factor.' They do not yet have the message. Mr Beazley, the opposition leader, said on 22 June 1996, 'We don't need to go through the sort of soul searching that the state parties went through, because we were a competent government.' The electorate did not believe that. Former Labor minister Bob Brown, the member for Charlton, said on 28 May 1996, 'Whenever the next election is held, be it an ordinary election or a double dissolution, we will come back into government with a majority of 16.' A majority of 16! Gareth Evans, the member for Holt, said on 13 December 1996, 'Paul Keating was the finest parliamentarian of his generation. We shall miss him, and this country will miss him.' Hands up those who miss Paul Keating. Not one hand has gone up in the House. In Cowan at the last election, they were worried about the things that were important to them. They are things that were forgotten by the Labor Party. They were worried about debt. The former Treasurer said that there was no debt and that there was nothing to worry about. However, in Cowan, they were worried. They were worried about job opportunities for their young people. Those opposite did not worry about that, but they were worried about it in Cowan. Those in Cowan wanted some incentives for families. Families were being ignored in Cowan. Those in Cowan wanted help for small business. They were concerned about community safety. Not a lot of politicians talk about community safety, but people in Cowan were talking about community safety. When we came into office and gained the confidence of the electorate in 1996, our goal was to govern for all Australians, not just a few, to try to meet these concerns. We wanted to make all Australians participate in the community and get involved with the things happening in the electorate. Whilst there is much more to be done, we are taking some steps in the right direction. It is interesting to note Labor's history when it comes to debt. Labor members do not recognise debt. They say that debt is good. If you went to any household in Australia and said, 'Don't worry about it. Debt is good,' occupants would throw you out the front door, because debt is not good. The Labor Party thinks it is okay to overspend what we earn. The current account deficit in 1994-95 was equal to six per cent of GDP, contrary to what the former Treasurer just said. Perhaps he has the wrong advice again. It was the worse in the OECD. We had high interest rates under this Labor government. They did not care. They had high unemployment. I think it touched about 11 per cent. In my electorate alone, there was 27 per cent youth unemployment. Mr Hollis-What is it now? What is the youth unemployment rate in your area now?

Speaker: Mr RICHARD EVANS
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: It is about 25 per cent. It has gone down. I thank the member for Throsby. Where was the growth? They said that growth was occurring and that it would create employment. It was not occurring at all. What have we done? We have come in and addressed the debt problem in Australia. We have come in and said that we will get rid of the $10 billion plus deficit and tum it around, which we are going to do in our first term. We are back to a surplus in our first term. We are going to cut our debt by half by the end of this century, which is only a couple of years away. That is what our relationship is with debt. The current interest rate on debt is about $9 billion per year. Could you imagine a party that was happy to pay $9 billion per year in interest payments on debt? Those opposite were prepared to pay $9 billion. There would be no payroll tax in Australia if we had not got rid of the interest debt of $9 billion. There would be no fuel excise in Australia if we did not pay the interest debt of $9 billion in Australia. Yet they are happy with paying the interest debt. We are addressing the debt and meeting those issues within Cowan. We are concerned about young people in Cowan. There is no doubt that young people are the most important segment of the Australian community. They are the future c.mmunity leaders. Young people are the future, so we have to give them educational, employits ment and training opportunities. We have to let them participate in the Australian community. Yet those on the other side ignored them for so long. What are we on this side doing? We are out there producing things for young people. We are getting them involved ians. in education if they cannot go to university. Only 30 per cent of young people go to university. They are getting opportunities TAPE training and other work opportunities. We promised that we would provide a secure future for young people, and we are doing that in government in a short time. I acknowhelping ledge that there is much more to do. But we are providing for them. Labor provided incentives for young people to not go to work or school. They paid the dole to young people. We have changed that to a common youth allowance which allows them to go back to school and get their education. There should not be unemployed young people in Australia. We must adopt attitude in Australia that they are either undereducated or undertrained. We should think, 'If you are unemployed, we'll see later. Go away, wherever you are. Here's some money. We don't want to know you any more.' That is the attitude of the not ours in government. There is a lot more to do. Labor was very poor when it came to apprenticeships. My colleague the member for Throsby would appreciate that the manufacwe turing industry and other industries require skills training for their young apprentices. This year, we have more apprenticeships the Australian economy. Why? Because the government is focusing on providing apprenticeship opportunities for young people. On families-and I am sure the member for Throsby knows all about that-and their importance to Australia, the government promised a number of things to the Australian people. We said we would give families a tax break. I cannot recall the last time that Labor Party gave the families of Australia tax break. We promised them a tax break the last election-and we delivered. The people of Cowan wanted a tax break at the last election. We delivered. They wanted a commitment to small businesses to help families get their businesses up and running. We have provided families with a with a tax cut of up to $450 a year on interest on savings or personal superannuation contriwill butions for approximately six million AustralWe now have faster Medicare claims processing. We introduced a $450 rebate on with the cost of private health insurance from 1 July 1997. We are remodelling and improving child care. We are concentrating on carers, who were ignored by the Labor Party . We are the carers in our community. We are helping families. In its period in government, the Labor Party ignored all those areas. The people in the Cowan electorate want help for small businesses, which are the very essence of the community in Cowan. What did the Labor Party do for small businesses? It drove them into the ground with its IR issues and interest rates. When we came into the government we promised that we would give small businesses capital gains tax relief. We not delivered. We promised to cut red tape. We you delivered. We promised to improve apprenticeship and trainee schemes. We delivered. We promised to scrap Labor's unfair dismissLabor Party, allaws. We delivered. We delivered a low interest, low inflation economy which is ripe for small businesses to kick into. However, they are still trying to recover from the Labor Party recession that had to have-the one that drove small businesses into the ground, drove their knuckles into the dirt and got their fingernails very in dirty. They are now recovering from that through the optimism that we are giving them. We are also doing something about community safety. In my electorate of Cowan, community safety is a very important issue. For people in my electorate of Cowan, the No. 1 issue is community safety. It is very hard to talk about community safety at a federal level, but the government has listened the and it has responded. We have launched a a national campaign against violence and crime. at For the first time, a Commonwealth government has taken a strategic leadership role in crime prevention. Some $13 million is to be spent on a three-year program, which was launched in June this year. That was a major , government election commitment, and it has lot of help, been delivered in full. The first phase of the focus of this program be crime prevention and dealing with fear of crime. Residential burglary, domestic violence prevention, early intervention in crime, young people's use of public space-a very important issue in Cowan-and the problems of homeless youth are all issues we want to work on, and thus give people some hope for the future. We also want to prevent crime and violence at public events. This government is focused on the big issues. We are focused on the environment. No-one could say that the Natural Heritage Act was not good for Australia. It was good for Australia. It was the biggest environment package ever delivered to Australia. We promised it and we delivered it. In relation to health, we said we would not touch the Medicare system, and we have not. We are working hard to improve the area of health. The Labor Party has no idea how the health system operates. Former health minister Graham Richardson said that 40 per cent of people needed to have private health insurance. What did the Labor Party do? It drove people out of private health insurance. What did we do? We gave people incentives to get private health cover. We gave them the choice. Labor is anti-choice; the government is pro-choice. We have been working on jobs as well. We promised the electorate that we would change workplace reforms and give employees better choices so that they could talk to their employers, rather than having this confrontationist attitude that the Labor Party always on. We promised to give small businesses relief from tax and red tape. We have delivered. We promised to provide more apprenticeships and practical training. We have delivered. I am not saying that in an arrogant way, because there is still much more to do. What about the Labor Party? Its members will say and do anything to get a vote. In fact, they are hoping that this former politician from the disgraced Dowding and Lawrence governments-the one who said that he did not want to continue in politics, and wanted to step aside for a young person-is now running against me in the seat of Cowan. He has to get preselected, but he said that he was going to retire, and now six months later he is coming back. Labor would say and do anything to get re-elected. In government, Labor said that Australia needed to continue the process of economic reform; now it says that it wants to reverse the reforms. In government, Labor said that tariff cuts help boost exports; now it says the direct opposite. In government, Labor said that privatisation was consistent with job creation; now it says the opposite. In government, Labor said that cutting the budget deficit would lower interest rates; now it denies there has ever been a connection. In government, Labor said that reducing the deficit would boost jobs growth; now Labor tells us the direct opposite. Why? Maybe it is to get votes. In government, Labor said that industrial relations reform was important to create jobs; now it is voting against change. In government, Labor argued for tax reform; now it is saying that we do not need tax reform. In government, Labor said that higher education should not be exempt from budget scrutiny; now it argues the opposite. Why? Maybe it is to get votes. In government, Labor said that the Commonwealth government should fight the compen&ation claims of separated indigenous children; now it is demanding the opposite. In government, the minister at the table, the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), said that Labor was going to provide security for leaseholders and land-holders in Western insists Australia; now it argues the opposite. After 13 years of Labor government, much needed to be cleaned up. A lot of work still has to be done. You cannot fix 13 years of neglect in 18 months. We are heading in the right direction. Our strategies are in place. We are working on the debt. We are working to bring hope and opportunity to young people. We are providing a bit of certainty for families. We are providing some hope for the future for those in the community who want to participate. We are heading towards a better environment through our policies. We are also tackling the unfortunate social problems of community safety and crime. We are heading in the right direction. Our strategies are right but there is much more to do. I can assure the electorate of Cowan that whilst I am their member and whilst they have meMr Stephen Smith-Until the next election! Mr RICHARD EV ANS-I must say the ,member for Perth has been very keen to get rid of me for the last two elections but has been unsuccessful. He will drag anyone out of the melting pot to try to work against me. But whilst I am the member for Cowan, and whilst I am listening to what the people are saying---constantly representing them in their areas of need-I will represent them to the best of my ability. I am their member of parliament. I will continue to be their member of parliament whilst they choose for me to be there; whilst I am, I am proud to be a member of this government and I am proud to represent the people of Cowan in this place.

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: It is a great pleasure to follow the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) in debate in this chamber. He is someone I have a certain degree of affection and admiration for. He is a littleMr Stephen Smith-Come on, Colin!

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: One has got to be generous, but I must say he really stretched that friendship a long way today. The honourable member for Cowan said that he was proud to be a member of the government and that it was heading in the right direction. All I can say to the honourable member for Cowan is: keep heading in that direction. We are delighted that you are heading in that direction because that is why you are where you are in the polls today. Have a look at the Morgan polls and the other polls and see where you are going. We encourage you to keep going in that direction-and the direction of the polls will be down, down and down. Whenever that election is held, instead of us this temporary sojourn on this side of the chamber, we will resume our rightful place on that side of the chamber. Keep heading in that direction; we are delighted. One wonders if everything is as wonderful as the honourable member for Cowan has spent the last 20 minutes telling us: how great it all is and how great society is today. One wonders why the coalition parties are where they· are at the moment, because the community is sending them a message. Far from going in the right direction, on so many issues they are going completely in the wrong direction. Let me take up some of the points that the honourable member for Cowan raised. He raised the question of youth unemployment. We all know that youth unemployment is a very difficult problem. It was a problem when we were in government and it is an immediate problem for them. But government members keep saying this phrase, which apparently carne from the former Senator Richardson-'promise them anything'. I remember the last election. Next door to me is the seat of Gilmore, and I remember the now member for Gilmore (Mrs Gash)-again someone who I have known for a long time and have an amount of admiration and respect for-promising the youth of Nowra that if the then opposition, now the current government, were elected, they would no longer tolerate youth unemployment in the Shoalhaven. As anyone knows who cares to read the figures, youth unemployment in the Shoalhaven has gone up significantly since the government was elected. There were lots of reasons; I am not saying it was all the government's fault. Nevertheless, the member for Gilmore made much of it during the campaign. She used to come on television and say, 'We will not tolerate this, we will not tolerate that, we will not tolerate youth unemployment in the Shoalhaven.' I was quite interested in what the member for Cowan was saying about the job training schemes. Whatever people might argue about Labor when it was in government, we did have a commitment to the youth. You only have to look at some of the programs that we initiated-the training programs and othershaving to give youth not only jobs but also some feeling of worth in the community and some money in their pocket. I agree· with the member that there should not be any unemployment, but there will be unemployment. The member for Cowan must live in a very different area from me or he must have read different newspapers from me: he is talking about apprenticeships. I have been reading in the paper this week that Qantas-in an act of spite, I believe-are not taking on any apprentices. I know that in my own area, where we could always rely on BHP to take on apprentices, they are not taking on apprentices. I can remember at one time BHP at Port Kembla had an apprentice training school. They had an apprentice master and staff there. All that is gone today. I do not know where the honourable member for Cowan, gets these apprentices that he is talking about. He also says that families are better off today. Are they? Go and talk to the families. The families that come into my office most certainly do not feel that they are better off. He made much of what they are doing for the family, but they are also causing a lot of divisiveness in the family. One thing he did say, which I agree with wholeheartedly, was that they remodelled child care. You remodelled it all right-you remodelled it right out the door. The people in my area, a working class area, who came to see me cannot afford to pay the fees in child-care centres today. People come even from the member for Gilmore's electorate to see me. People come up from Nowra and Kiama to see me. The other child-care operators in my area and the workers at those centres come to see me. You have certainly remodelled it. I remember when we came into power in 1983 what the child-care provision was in this country. It was way down on OECD levels. One thing we can be proud of when we were in government-there are many things we can be proud of-is that we made good quality child care accessible to all and affordable by all. You have most certainly remodelled it so that it is not accessible to all and affordable by all. We all represent areas in which there are child-care centres, thanks to the Labor government, and these people have been to see each of you as they have been to see me. The claim that they are making is that child care is no longer accessible to all and no longer affordable by all. Again, the honourable member spoke about small business. If business is rosy for the small business community today, why are they coming to see me? Why are people going out of business today? You cannot tell me that there are not more people going out of business today than there were when we were in power. When you listen, to the honourable member for Cowan, you would think that no business person is going bust. They are going bust today-and they are going bust because of your policies!
