So let us hear no more of this nonsense about small business. Small business people are not our traditional supporters. They do not vote for us; in the past they have not. You will see where they are going to cast their vote at the next election. I am afraid, colleagues, it will not be for you. I am so grateful to the honourable member for Cowan for making such a wide ranging speech because I did not have a lot prepared. He has given me the opportunity to respond to his comments. He touched on Medicare and said that Medicare is preserved. You are trying to gut Medicare; you are trying to kill it by 1,000 stabs. Let me tell you of the commitments made during the election campaign. In the last federal election campaign, the Liberal candidate for the seat of Throsby was a chicken farmer from Liverpool-he did not even live in the electorate. This chicken farmer-we called him 'the chickel1 man'fluttered into my electorate on one day during the four or five weeks campaign. For some time, there had been a campaign in my electorate to open ,a new Medicare office at Dapto. I was very involved in this. It was put through the Dapto branch of the ALP and many people came to see me. The combined pensioners were running a campaign on it. There were letters in the paper and it went over a couple of years. When Graham Richardson was a minister, I remember a deputation went to see him. When the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) was a minister, we had a meeting here. We said to the people, 'In the growth projected for Dapto, in a couple of years time there will be the population base for a Medicare office and I am sure we will eventually establish a Medicare office there.' They were a bit angry with me and the government that we had not immediately seen the validity of their arguments and immediately opened a Medicare office in Dapto. But we had produced all the figures to show that, in the long term, we would open it. The chicken man came down campaigning against me in the seat of Throsby on his one day. His big announcement on the television that night and in the local newspapers was, the Liberal Party is elected to government, we will immediately open a Medicare office in Dapto.' 'Great news,' everyone said. Everyone was ringing me up and saying, 'The chicken man'-whatever his name was-'is so successful he is going to open a Medicare office in Dapto.' As history records, the Liberal and National parties won the federal election and we waited with bated breath for the Medicare office to open in Dapto. What did you do? Instead of opening one, you closed two Medicare offices. You closed the Medicare office at Warrawong and you closed the Medicare office at Corrimal! Instead of giving us an additional Medicare office in Dapto, which was a solemn promise from the Liberal Party, immediately they won the election, what did they do? Instead of opening one, they closed two. Unbelievable! And they are expecting us to believe that they are not determined to destroy Medicare. Now we come to the environment. Unless things have moved a little more quickly than I have known them to move, the whole question on the environment is still a promise. It is still a gleam in some Liberal Party member's eye. Like us, you are committed to the environment, but do you think that it will really be delivered? Why are the environmental movements throughout Australia, those who you conned, so worried about you? It is all very well for Liberal Party members to stand up in this chamber and say that the Labor Party would promise us anything. Any of us who lived through the last election know the sleazy deal you did with the environmental movement. The deal that was done then was not delivered on. So don't you people lecture us on promising anything to get government. You promised anything to the environmental movement and, as I always say to the environmentalists when they come to see me, the problem with the Liberal Party is that they have the chainsaw wielding National Party to contend with-the chainsaw gang. You are a coalition and you always have to go for the lowest common denominator and accommodate the chainsaw wielding National Party members. You know that. Whatever you 'If may want individually to deliver on the environment, you always have to deal with the chainsaw gang. They are the ones who are going to dictate what is delivered on the environment. Okay, there may be some desalination of rivers, there may be a few more trees planted, but the real question on the environment will be what the chain saw gang say it is going to be. You know that and I know that. So let us wait and see, instead of talking as if you have already delivered. You have made a promise but the goods have not yet been delivered and I doubt whether they will be before the next election. I do not want to go on about the indigenous people, although the honourable member for Cowan did. It is a debate that is going on at the moment so perhaps it is not appropriate to delve into that, but let me say that there are a lot of disappointed and disillusioned people there. Moving on to workplace reform, most workplace reform-and I notice it has been in the media this week-is to do with the waterfront. It always amazes me that, when those opposite talk about the waterfront, they talk as if taking the W aterside Workers Federation of Australia membership out, lining them up against a wall and shooting them would immediately solve all the problems on the waterfront. Of all the trade union movements in Australia, the Maritime Union of Australia-the former Waterside Workers Federation of Australia-is the most reformed. The shipping unions are the unions which have been most reformed over recent years. It is a lean and mean team on waterfront today. A few years ago on the waterfront a lot of people could be seen. They are not seen today. The union movement has been restructured. The waterfront is an extremely complex business. There are a lot of cogs in the chain there and the waterfront workers are but few. I hear the people over on the other side talking about the waterfront, but how many times when ships are being loaded do farmers or producers not deliver the goods on time? They leave it until the last possible minute. Those on the other side talk about truck queues outside the wharves. How many of them ever ask or even realise how many truckies are paying off their trucks through demurrage? They are stuck there because of waiting time. What about the number of times stuff is taken off the ships and left there by people for three days? We should start being sensible about the waterfront. We should start charging storage time to keep goods on the waterfront instead of it being a cheap method of storing goods. We should do something about the paperwork, about bills of lading. We should have an electronic exchange and things like that instead of this grab bag of ideas that people are always putting up. People are always arguing about the waterfront and saying, 'We've got to do something about the wharfies.' That is a nonsense. Those on the other side are very keen to read out letters that they receive from constituents. It seems that the constituents who write to those opposite are always very critical of the Labor Party and always full of praise for the good things that those opposite are doing. I-like, I guess, many other members-received a letter this week from the Missionary Sisters of Service in Queensland. It was signed by some 50 other people. It said: Dear Mr Hollis This letter is being sent to each of our Federal politicians. A nun wrote this letter. The letter continues: In all my 58 years of life I have never felt so disillusioned at the Federal Government, yet wondering how we, the citizens of this country can be heard by those supposedly representing us. I feel much shame at John Howard's decision on the standards of output of greenhouse gas emissions-he is an embarrassmentI am not saying this-I would not say this about our Prime Minister-this is what this sister, this nun, is sayingto our country as he promotes a policy that brings long term damage to our planet, saying that jobs and industry in Australia are higher priorities. I think that your stand on greenhouse gas emissions is a disgrace. I represent a coal producing area; I've got a lot of coalminers in my area. Last week, the Prime Minister stood in this House, pointed out to us who represented coal miners and said that he was working to save their jobs. I got on to the union and asked them. They said that no way-this is right from the top: John Maitland and others· right down to the coalminers in my area-did they support the Prime Minister's view on greenhouse gas emissions. He should stop using that argument. We all know the tragedy that a goods and services tax would be, especially for the lower paid people in Australia. He also talked about selling off government owned assets. Our record is not all that good on that either, so I will not debate that issue. I must say that I have always, even when we were in government, opposed selling off our assets. I am one of the few from this side who is on the public record as standing up in this chamber and opposing what we were doing there. This letter also says the question of Aboriginal reconciliation is being poorly handled by our government---one wonders if it will ever be resolved-and says that the decision to impor.t pork and chicken meat means that our local primary producers will eventually be put out of business. This is just one letter. I am sure that members opposite have received this letter. In future, when those opposite read out their letters we will trot out some of the letters we get that show that everything is not as rosy as the honourable member for Cowan would have us believe. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr NUGENT
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: I think the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) gave a spirited defence of the former government. Considering the damage that they did to this country over a lengthy period of time, I think it took a lot of courage for him to stand up and make some of those statements. I would like to deal with a few of the comments that he made. I do not intend to produce a letter; I just want to calmly deal with a few of the facts of life. I also caught a few of the remarks earlier on by the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe). There is a fairly consistent theme emerging from the other side in this debate. They conveniently forget the damage that they did in government. The legacy that they left was not just left to this government; it was also imposed on the people of Australia-a very poor legacy it is, too. They have jumped from that situation, glossed over the unfortunate damage that they did and started berating us for not having fixed all those ills in 19 or 20 months in government. For example, the member for Maribyrnong talked about growth and unemployment, and the fact that he did not think there was any commitment from this side to fix unemployment. On that subject, I remind the House that the previous government ran very high unemployment rates for very many years and tried all sorts of programs, special initiatives, and special legislation, spent literally billions dollars on special unemployment programs and so on, and still were unable to fix the problem. Although the unemployment rate today obviously remains at a totally unacceptably high level and is something that does cause all of us concern and that we all are trying to find ways to deal with, to suggest that that is something that has occurred under us or that could be fixed very quickly under us is, frankly, very hypocritical, given that after 13 years the previous government was not able to fix the unemployment problem in general and the youth unemployment problem in particular. The member for Throsby, who has just been speaking, raised a number of points. He also went down the route of unemployment, and particularly youth unemployment. He talked about the impact of some of the things that we have done. He talked about the way we have remodelled some of the services out there in the community. Mr Hollis-The member for Cowan said that, not me.

Speaker: Mr NUGENT
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: The member for Throsby us-d the word 'remodelling', so I quote his own words. The point that I want to make is that I think there is a fundamental truth that the gentleman opposite needs to understand. You get to the point-and we saw it at a federal level; and I come from Victoria, and certainly saw it with the last Labor government in Victoria-that you can get into debt for a certain period of time, but you cannot just keep running up the bill forever and ever. Two things happen. One is that you have to pay interest on your borrowings, and that becomes a larger and larger proportion of your recurrent expenditure, which therefore means that the amount of disposable money you have to spend on services diminishes. The second thing is that if your debt gets too high those from whom you have borrowed the money will actually move in and will not give you the freedom and the flexibility to sort out your own problem; they will impose solutions. What happened with the previous government is that they were getting increasingly of into debt. So when we came to government less than two years ago, we inherited a very adverse financial situation. Therefore, it is important on a national scale as well as in our own home budgeting-and I think everybody can relate to home budgeting-that if you are living beyond your means ultimately there comes a point in time when you have to take some fairly drastic action. This government had to take that action. I notice that unfortunately the honourable member for Throsby, who was making so many complaints, has not stayed around in the chamber to listen to the response to what he had to say. Of course, we know that it is pretty unpalatable from the opposition point of view. The reality was that we inherited a $10 billion shortfall in the government's budget and we have had to try to put that right. Nobody suggests at all that that has been without pain. Of course, it has been painful. It has been painful in a number of areas of government expenditure. And a lot of the decisions that we have had to make have often been a choice between two unpalatable options. Sometimes it is a question of doing less damage in one area than you might do in another area. But of course we have felt pain. I also draw the parallel I mentioned earlier of the situation in Victoria. The Kennett government, before the Howard government, had to undertake a similar exercise in terms of the Victorian economy. And Victoria is now very much getting back on their feet. They have paid off much of the debt and are able to now start to spend some more money in the services area of education, health, and so on. So they are getting back on their feet. Clearly, that is the route that the federal national government has to undertake. It is no good the other side talking about what we have done to child care or what we might have done to health or education or complaining about any of those other areas. The reality of life is that they had 13 years government to put all those things into place. And had there been a paid for, effective, operating set of systems in those areas when we came to government, then there would have been no need for us to take the painful action that we have had to take. So it seems to me that if they could not fix those problems in 13 years they are really speaking with forked tongue or, at the most charitable, with tongue in cheek, in standing here and complaining that we have not fixed the unemployment problem or that we had to take some of these strong measures in a relatively brief period of government. Like the Queen Mary or any other large ship or tanker, if you are sailing along in a particular direction, you cannot just change direction very quickly; it does take time for these matters to work through. We would all like to see it happen a lot more quickly. We would all like to see improvements occur without any pain. But the reality is that we have to deal in the real world and not in the wishful thinking world. The member for Throsby talked about small business. He complained about the fact that there were still small businesses going bust. As I am sure you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I know many other members of this chamber will be aware, small businesses go bust on an ongoing basis. To say that there are a few small businesses going bust today is in itself obviously regrettable in the individual cases, but it does not actually mean a thing in termS of looking at what the government has done. The reality is that small businesses were going bust at a far greater rate under the previous government than they are under this government. In fact, this government has introduced a number of measures that have helped small business very significantly. I was very disappointed when the member for Throsby talked about small business. One of the things that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology did recently was to conduct an inquiry into the operation of small business, which looked at predatory practices of large companies against small companies, in retail tenancies and a whole range of other issues that are of critical importance to small business. That inquiry received a lot of input from small business. When its recommendations were published they were lauded by the whole small business sector and all their spokesmen. This government picked up those recommendations and not only implemented them fully but in some areas went even further. Again, the whole small business sector stood up and applauded what this government has done. And that was on top of earlier measures that we had taken in terms of capital gains tax-measures aimed at helping small business. Of course, there are always problems out there. Nobody is suggesting that the small business climate is perfect, but the reality is that this government has done a great number of things for small business. It was interesting that the member for Throsby talked about Medicare. He said that this government is 'trying to destroy Medicare by 1,000 stabs'. That is not the case. We have not, in any shape or form, tried to destroy Medicare. In fact, closing the odd Medicare office is often a matter of prudent administration when you decide to open an office here or close an office there. Obviously cost factors and population shift come into it, and clearly, on an ongoing basis, offices will be closed from time to time and new offices will be opened. It seems to me that whether you have got a Medicare office or not is not the core of whether you are destroying Medicare. Medicare is about delivering medical and hospital services to people. We are not talking about the administration. If the strongest point the member for Throsby can make is that we have closed some Medicare offices, he has not got much to complain about at all. What the member for Throsby did not mention was that in the 13 years of the previous government there had been a very considerable degradation of medical facilities available to people in this country, particularly in the private health sector where, under the previous government, we saw participation in private health insurance drop from around 70 per cent down to around 32 or 33 per cent. What that meant was that those people not only. were taken out of the private health area, which left a number of facilities underutilised, but then went on to the public health system which, in tum, put huge stresses and strains on the public health system. That has caused much more damage to the health system in this country than our closing a few Medicare offices around the trapsThe member for Throsby also talked about waterfront reform. He painted a graphic picture about us wanting to take out people from the waterfront, line them up and do terrible things to them. That is not what the argument is about at all. He said that they were lean and mean, there had been a lot of reform and we were performing much better on the waterfront. I agree with him. We are performing much better on the waterfront. He also talked about the problem of people not collecting their goods, resulting in the goods being left for three days on the wharf, and said that perhaps we should do something about that. I agree with that. The reality of life is that, although we have improved handling on the waterfront-let us talk about handling on the waterfront: the loading and unloading of ships and so on-in the last few years, and there is no argument about that, we function in an internationally competitive environment. What we have done on the waterfront has been an improvement, but it has not been a sufficient improvement. Five years ago on the Melbourne waterfrontand Melbourne is one of the largest ports around the traps in our neck of the woodswe were handling something like 11 containers an hour. That figure, up until a couple of years ago, had improved to about 25 or 26 containers an hour-a significant improvement. The trouble is that if you look at Singapore, which is one of our competitors, five years ago they were already handling 20 or 21 containers an hour. We are up to 25, but they are now at 45 and so, in relative terms, in competitive terms, we have gone backwards. That is why people on this side of the chamber are talking about the need to improve our performance on the waterfront. It does not matter how effective and efficient our manufacturers or our road transport systems are if, when goods get to the waterfront, the costsand we are talking about cost of ultimately delivering to the customer overseas-of slow handling, of getting things through, of the number of employees needed to handle a particular container load and so on are uncompetitive with our overseas rivals. It has been well established in the waterfront area that because of the handling costs and often because of other transport problems as well you can often produce goods in America or Japan, ship them here and quite frequently land them at a price that is much more competitive. I think the member for Throsby really does have to look very hard at the realities of life. It is not just measuring where we were before; you have to look at where we are with the rest of the world. In debating this Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1997-98, the Appropriation Bill (No.4) 199798 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No.2) 1997-98, it is important that we look at the broad sweep of economic activity. Obviously, any specific proposals that are brought to this chamber have to be looked at in the context of the overall state of the economy. It seems to me that there are a couple of perspectives: you can look at it from a broad national perspective or you can look at how it affects people on the ground. I am not one of those who says, 'Let's just get the gross numbers right.' Let us look at how it affects people on the ground. My electorate of Aston is in· the outer eastern suburbs of Melbourne, about 30 kilometres due east of the centre of the city. The profile of my electorate is overwhelmingly young, with lots of young families, lots of small business, very few public servantsinterestingly enough-and not many older people. We have more mortgage payers than any other electorate in the country. In other words, my electorate is the mortgage belt of Australia. This government has done a number of very significant things in a short period of timewe have not fixed everything; we have a long way to go and we are the first to say thatfor people who live in my electorate, which is typical of many suburban electorates around the country and typical of middle Australia. We obviously have had to work hard to put the budget in surplus, which will happen in the next budget year, and then we will be in a position to be a bit more generous with a few things. There has been some pain with that but, because of this prudent financial approach, we are in the fortunate position where we have got not only zero inflation but also interest rates down to the lowest level in living memory for most of the people who live in my electorate. When I was elected to this chamber in 1990, home interest rates in my electorate were around 16 or 17 per cent and small business interest rates were 22 or 23 per cent. Today home interest rates are, as we all know, around the six per cent mark and business interest rates are a bit higher. For people in my electorate who are buying their homes-and I might add that per capita incomes in my electorate are not particularly high but household incomes are quite high, which tells you that both husband and wife are working because they have had to pay off those big mortgages-the decline in interest rates means a saving of several hundred dollars a month. That is a significant and very specific benefit brought to the people of my electorate and many other parts of Australia by the responsible fiscal management of this government. We have achieved in less than two years something that the previous government could not do in 13 years. So I frankly find it pretty hollow when people stand up on the other side and complain about what we are doing. We have started to deliver a number of the things that are very important. I might also mention that, in terms of people on the ground, we all remember a previous Prime Minister from the other side and his infamous l-a-w tax cuts which never occurred. This government went to the last election campaigning on giving a family tax package-a series of tax cuts-which we delivered within 12 months of coming to government. We put it in our first budget, they were paid on the 1 January, and people have had those benefits in their pocket. Those are two very simple, straightforward examples of where this government's financial policy has been very successful. Of course, there are other things we need to do. My time is running out and I have not got time to go into a whole range of other issues, but I want to conclude by saying that I commend these particular bills to the House. We need to remember they are just a micro-part of a broader scenario wlti.ch is delivering benefits to people in Australia. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: I take great pleasure in following the member for Aston (Mr Nugent), one of those in this House who is prepared to speak out on matters of fairness and justice, and I listened with great interest to his comments. I realise he strongly supports the government's economic policies, but I suspect he may have a struggle at times with defending the economic rationalist philosophy. He is a person for whom I have a great deal of time and respect. One of the most disturbing political news stories to emerge over the past week would have to be the decision by the National Party to scale down its national headquarters here in Canberra. I say this in the context of these bills, the Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1997-98, the Appropriation Bill (No.4) 1997-98 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No.2) 1997-98. I am trying to set out the fact that, whatever this government and the one before might do in an economic sense, I believe they are being driven by a theory about economic performance which is perhaps getting the bottom line right and delivering growth in one sense, but it is not having the desired impact on, or the return for, regional Australia. I think patience is running out in the regions, and I want to raise a few issues which I think the government and the opposition could well take on board in framing their policies down the track. I think there needs to be a softening. That is not to say that you give away the bottom line economics, but the equation needs to include something that I call 'social economics'-not socialism. I think we are lacking that and, in doing so, we are missing the point and letting down a lot of people out there. According to the reports, the decision to close down the national headquarters of the National Party was taken because membership of the party has fallen off dramatically. It gives me no great pleasure to draw attention to the fact that I think the reason why the National Party is losing members is that so many people in rural and regional Australia are suffering. After 13 years of Labor in government, the people of rural and regional Australia had very high expectations of this government when they overwhelmingly voted in support of the coalition in last year's election. But, where they believed there was a viable option, they took out an insurance policy and gave support to Independents-we can all debate the wisdom of that, I suppose-and strong support to the options that were available in the Senate. The National Party's membership crisis is a clear illustration that people's expectations have not been met. It is fair to say there are many reasons. Perhaps some people's expectations were too high. Politics is, by its very nature, a field of endeavour where you cannot please all the people all the time. I think it is fair to say that the gulf between the major cities and rural Australia has continued to widen in the last 20 months. The sandstone curtain, as I call the Blue Mountains, separating my electorate from Sydney has grown even higher it seems. When I came to this place last year, in my first speech I highlighted many of the problems facing people in rural and regional Australia. I said how I felt I was elected because there was so much disillusionment with the major political parties that when given a credible choice of candidates who were not part of the system voters were happy to take a gamble with an independent. Certainly the recent South Australian election and the last by-election in Victoria have demonstrated that that trend has not changed since the federal election in March 1996. I cannot ever recall a period in my life when I have heard so many people decry what they see as a lack of leadership in this country. That is probably very unfair to the current government in some regards because right around the world we are seeing the difficulties people are having in coming to terms with the internationalisation and the globalisation of their economies and the trade liberalisation programs, where, in the case of many Australian farmers, they are not seeing the sort of return they were led to expect would be there nor do they see it happening at any point further down the track. Now we see the partial collapse of some Asian economies or at least extensive difficulties in their economies. We see a devaluation of their particular currencies. We now have the prospect of even cheaper imports from. those markets that we are battling to contend with, with their current protection regimes. With the problems that are being demonstrated in the Asian economies at the moment there are people out there who are perhaps a bit unsophisticated in their economic understanding but who see more danger signals on top of those that have been piling up over the past couple of years and the past few months and they are saying that the situation is looking even worse for us. Not only are we having to prop up-and I have no difficulty with propping up these economies because therein lies our future market potential-but they see further danger signs ahead and they say, 'What are we sacrificing in the interests of trade liberalisation and when will we derive our benefit?' It is a very difficult job for the government to sell these policies. There also seems to be a misunderstanding by this government that getting the bottom line right is enough on its own. Social economics is not part of the equation. What is the cost of not putting more money into, say, our rail infrastructure? What is the cost of not having heavy freight on rail instead of on roads where we are using our scarce road dollars to chase the heavy transports along inadequate routes to repair and restore them? If we again made some sort of public commitment to our rail infrastructure we could then privatise to the point of offering a fair access rate to the people who would use that rail network. I have said before that TNT have told me that they would access the main western line but for the Carr government's access charges. They are a factor of four or five out of the ballpark. This just does not make sense. It seems the Carr government wants a return to the user pays principle without any consideration of the down side of not offering that infrastructure at a reasonable rate and what it is costing in terms of road damage. That is just one example. The other part of social economics is the cost of not providing a proper public service out there in the bush so that people, many of whom are ageing, can rapidly access real people. I notice that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) has taken steps to remedy this in his area by training people in Orange and Oberon to provide veteran services. There is a real feeling out there amongst not just the older people in the bush that they cannot cope with a lot of technology such as the 1800 numbers and more and more they need people on the ground to talk to. There is one financial information service officer to service the whole Bathurst-Orange-Oberon district at a time when there are all of these changes to aged care deli very, general welfare deli very , the youth allowance and Austudy. All these things require people sitting down one on one, looking at particular circumstances and working it out. The people who are there are overworked. They cannot make enough appointments. They need more assistance, It is a cost to the bottom line, but it is certainly not a cost in terms of delivering services to the electorate. We have had three to four per cent economic growth without any improvement in the unemployment figures, particularly in the regions. We are dealing with an electorate which is highly intelligent and volatile. They know they had services before. They know they enjoyed a standard of living before. Why things have changed, particularly economic theories, has not been properly understood. I had someone ring me the other day and say, 'Why is the Prime Minister advocating foreign takeovers of one our major banks or foreign investment in our banking system? Wouldn't it be better if we maintained control of that ourselves?' The internationalisation and deregulation of the financial market has not been explained. It has been done at a level of debate above which the general population can't climb let alone partake in. It is very obvious that. all of these things come to bear in the city of Lithgow-a very resilient place, battered by all the forces of economic rationalism, downsizing, bank privatisation, withdrawal of services and so on. It is a regional centre that has copped it all over the last little while. Still it is fighting back. Only yesterday, the city suffered yet another blow with the closure of the Berlei bra factory after 50 years of operation. On the news last night we did not see them sitting glumly, we saw them painting faces on their staff and playing around-enjoying the last moment together, rather than, necessarily, saying, 'Woe are we.' But woe certainly are they because for most of those women that was their family's sole source of income. They cannot just up and move into the city, over the mountains and look for other work. Many of them, if they are not sole parents, are the wives of people in the coal mining industry500 of whom, out of a work force of 1,500, will have lost their jobs by August next year. Lithgow is the town where Ben Chifley is still held in such high regard that his portrait takes centre place in the city council chambers,with the Duke and the Queen about six inches lower on either side. There is a certain symbolism in their appreciation of what Ben stood for. Ben's policies of nationalisation may be well out of date by now, but his belief in the benign hand of government in the economy should certainly not be out of date. That is what is lacking in the economic theories that are part of these appropriation bills and the economic policies of this and the previous government. I notice, though, that the opposition is starting to deal with these issues. They are not easy ones, I know. You cannot tum back the clock. We cannot pull up the drawbridge-as my colleague the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) might want to dobut we can certainly listen and explain a lot more than we are at the moment. Lithgow, for instance, was the strongest Labor voting area in NSW, but today the people of Lithgow are not as loyal as they once were. They are willing to swing their votes if they are not offered better alternatives. Despite the battering the city has ped, there are still people in Lithgow with a lot more vision than you will find in Canberra amongst the people advising. I recently met with local union officials to discuss the problems facing the coal industry. As I said, 500 coal mining jobs out of 1,500 will be gone by August of next year. International coal mining companies do not give a stuff about the welfare of their workers. They see them merely as units of labour. With international prices for coal now so low-the 'great' Australian, BHP, has gone out into the spot market and got contracts at $26 a tonne; it costs $17 a tonne to get the coal from the western fields onto the boat at Port Kemblathere is no margin there. I am not blaming one particular foreign operator for that. You cannot use that excuse. I believe there is a policy at work here to batter the unions into submission. Some of them need a bit of a clout around the ears about some of their work practices, but coal mining is a filthy, dangerous job. They are up to their waists in water sometimes. The western field is underground. It is fraught with dangers. We have had tragedies within the last 10 years in that area. Unfortunately, we will probably see more. But those people are prepared to go down there, as their fathers did, and dig out coal. They do not get a huge reward for that, but they certainly require some sort of return of faith from their employer, which they are not getting in many cases. Having spoken to the coal industry unions, I can assure the Prime Minister that these workers are well aware of the debate over the greenhouse gas targets. They are not sticking their head in the coal, in the ground or in the mine and saying, 'We do not want to know about it.' They realise that we cannot keep digging black rock out of the ground and burning it forever. We have to look at alternatives. Likewise, farmers in my electorate have been absolutely dumbfounded by this government's decision to cut off support for - he emerging ethanol fuel industry. It was killed off with the ethanol bounty system that was to deliver $21 million by the year 2000 cop- to get what was developing into a very feasible industry under way. The Manildra group and CSR have had to can that operation. What do we get in its place? A program worth a couple of million dollars for an ethanol pilot plant. They had the dashed things going, and we canned it. What commitment is there to any sort of alternative energy policy? I have had a suggestion from fanners out in the Mudgee area for carbon trading. Why are we not pushing that harder? Are we going to push it at Kyoto? There is potential for trading carbon world wide. We are in a prime position to be planting the trees for the carbon sinks that can develop income streams for farmers-I am not talking about harvesting trees; I am talking about measuring the carbon uptake and issuing certificates. They become tradeable commodities on the Australian or the world market as a trade-off for carbon dioxide emissions. That is perhaps what we should be looking at so we can trade off our emissions without any helter-skelter rush to reduce our emissions, costing jobs. Jobs will be created in the alternative energy industry if we do it creatively. Why do we not put more money and support into research into alternative energies alongside those greenhouse emission industries-the coal fired power industry and the coal mining industry, in areas like the Bowen Basin of Queensland. Let those areas become the areas for research programs into wind and solar energy so the people involved in the carbon creating industries can see, developing alongside them, the alternative that will, inevitably, be the source of energy that we will have to adopt. Then they can see that there can be jobs created-it is not just killing off their industry-and it will not become a political short-term problem about votes next time. I have votes down there in the coal ing industry too. It would be safe for me to ,stand up here and say, 'Let's protect the coal mining industries-all. of those jobs.' But I am prepared to stick my neck out, and so are the coal unions, to open up the debate without just hiding behind the fear of lost voting opportunities that might be out there. That is such a short-sighted vision. Parliament is three years. If we have a double dissolution, for heaven's sake, it might only be two. Let us not even contemplate that. Again, with a little bit of explanation and debate about native title, people in my electorate are understanding what it is all about. They might not necessarily agree with my point of view, but they are certainly better educated about it, and I cannot recall one complaint in the last six months about native title. On the contrary, it has been a very supportive electorate for the principles of delivering to our indigenous people a true native title that means something-not freehold, but something that offers them something to work with down the track with perhaps negotiation for commercial gain at some point. Recognition of native title is what they basically require and my electorate is supporting that. Having said that, I support these bills with a warning that you have to get a little more of the social economics into the equation. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr TAYLOR
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: Groom) (1.31 p.m.)Before the honourable member for Calare (Mr Andren) leaves the chamber, I would like to thank him for what was a very balanced, perceptive and intuitive insight into the way many people out there see the contemporary issues that face us at the moment. That is not to say that I agree with everything he said, particularly some of his economic theories. Nevertheless, I think his contribution today reinforces a view that this chamber is the richer for having some independent thought. On that point, I am very pleased that he differentiated his views-and this would be the case with the views of the members for Moore (Mr Filing) and Curtin (Mr Rocher)from the more extreme partisan views of the members for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) and Oxley (Ms Hanson). I thank him for a balmin- anced contribution to this debate. Appropriation Bill (No.3) mentions a $111,121,000 allocation of appropriations to the Department of Defence. Of that, a little over $88 million is for equipment and stores. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) made the point that this appropriation was for high priority logistic items, including spares and equipment repair activities. One thing that does frustrate and disappoint me at times in this place-and indeed as I look at the record of the other place-is the degree to which national security and strategic issues are not debated comprehensively. There are but a handful of people in this place and in the other who attempt to address some of these issues. I am not being unduly critical, because there are, in some people's views, more important portfolio, public policy issues that need to be addressed. I am very pleased that the opposition spokesman for defence, the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), is here because I am about to talk about defence. I also congratulate him on some of his balanced views, although I do not agree with him all the time, either. Nevertheless, as the opposition spokesman, he provides a balanced view on government policy and undoubtedly at times disagrees with that policy. What I want to do in the time available to me today is talk a little about defence funding generally, the defence efficiency review-one of the commendable initiatives of the present Minister for Defence (Mr MCLachlan)-and the ongoing defence reform program. Finally, I will relate back to my comments in terms of the defence logistic expenditure and the item in Appropriation Bill (No.3) and talk a little about the Australian National Audit Office report No.5, which was highly critical of the performance management of the defence industry. Assessing the level of funding required for the defence of Australia is a complex and challenging task. It involves judgments about likely political, diplomatic, economic and industrial trends, it involves developments in our increasingly sophisticated and uncertain regional security environment, and it involves the rate of advance of technology and the changing nature of warfare. It also involves careful assessments about the level of assurance required by, or conversely the level of risk likely to be acceptable to, the Australian government and the community in the provision of their defence. Government policy is to assure the promotion of Australia's security and the protection of its people and interests through the development and the maintenance of the self-reliant capability to defeat any use or threat of armed force against Australia. It is important to note that capability is the combination of force structure and its preparedness and encompasses equipment, trained people to operate that equipment, facilities and the total support required to operate efficiently and effectively. Preparedness comprises readiness, which is the ability of forces to carry out operations within specified time frames, and also sustainability, which is the support required, including personnel aspects, consumables and the maintenance of systems to sustain operations for specified periods. Defence funding has traditionally been measured in terms of the proportion of the nation's or the government's resources allocated to defence. The 1997-98 budget of a little over $10.4 billion represents 1.9 per of gross domestic product and 8.2 per cent of Commonwealth outlays. These proportions have declined over the last decade, from 2.6 per cent and nine per cent respectively in 1986-87. In comparison, the proportion of Commonwealth outlays for health, social security and education has grown from 12 to 16.3 per cent, 27.2 to 40.1 per cent and 6.8 to 8.2 per cent respectively over the same period, and the percentage of GDP for each department has also grown over this period. Put another way, defence funding has been reduced in real terms in recent years by 0.75 per cent in 1993-94, 0.5 per cent in 1994-95, 0.5 per cent in 1995-96 and again 0.5 per cent in 1996-97. This represents an ongoing reduction of some $230 million per annum compared with pre 1993-94 levels. For the period 1997-98 to 1999-2000, defence funding is planned to remain constant at zero per cent real growth. Given anticipated growth in GDP, defence outlays are forecast to be 1.8 per cent of GDP at the end of this period. Whilst percentages of GDP or overall Commonwealth outlays provide useful measures of trends in spending-for example, these figures demonstrate that there has been a relative decline in Australia's spending on defence compared with the major areas of Commonwealth outlays-they do not provide an objective b\lsis for the amount of funding that should be provided to a specific function. For example, much depends on the movement in GDP itself. Australia's GDP has grown in real terms from 1986-87 to 1996-97 by some 33 per cent. If defence outlays had remained at 2.6 per cent of GDP, as they were in those earlier dates, the 1997-98 defence outlays would have been a little over $14.2 billion, and I compare that with the $10.4 billion that is included in the 1997-98 appropriations. However, the level of funding for defence needs to be determined not on the basis of share of GDP, but rather on the basis of overall government objectives in terms of fiscal policy, a realistic assessment of the resources that government will be able to allocate to defence, the strategic environment and the task to be achieved in the defence area. To achieve an acceptable level of risk cent necessitates a balance between defence tasks and resources. Should the resources required to achieve the task not be available, the level of risk will of course increase. The government and the Australian community rightly expect Defence to use its funding wisely. The government must also ensure that full value is being achieved for the resources allocated to defence-that is, that existing resources are being used in the most effective and efficient manner possible. Turning quickly to the defence efficiency review and the defence reform program, I wish to refer specifically to excerpts from a couple of speeches the Minister for Defence gave a few months ago and highlight one or two points he made. About six months ago in one of those speeches he said: The reasons why the Government embarked on the Defence Reform Program are, in fact, very simple. He went on to say: Prior to the Efficiency Review, the Defence Organisation was not many years away from facing a severe budget crisis brought on by a need to replace ageing equipment reaching block obsolescence. The problem would have peaked after the turn of the century, when our need to address that block obsolescence for major equipment across the services far exceeded the levels of resources likely to be available. He went on to say: The Defence Department was drifting towards a point where the only choice was to cut capability. In fact, that was no realistic choice at all. Defence had been making reforms designed to bring in savings. But the Commercial Support Programand a very commendable programand a number of other initiatives were not producing enough to solve the problem. As he said: The Defence Efficiency Review aimed to change how we do business to prevent us cutting military capabilities not many years from now. He also went on in that same speech to differentiate between the defence efficiency review and the strategic review, and I hope we will hear a little more on the latter in the ministerial statement from the Minister for Defence which, I understand, could be as early as next week. He said: Some commentators have said that we got the Efficiency Review and the Strategic Review the wrong way around. I have to say privately that I was one of those; I thought at the time that we did get them back to front. He went on to say: They are wrong. And I think he is right. In hindsight, I think the order was about right. As he said: The DER was not about-and was never intended to be about-setting strategic and spending priorities. That will come with the Strategic Review, which I put in train well before the DER. The Strategic Review will set the directions, equipment and capability priorities for the future. And it will be completed before the Reform Program starts to free resources. We wait with interest to see what he mayor may not have to say on that sometime next week. In a second speech about a month later, the minister went into much greater detail, and I really do not have time to do that today. He talked about the specific measures under the defence refonn program in tenns of policy and strategic guidance, in tenns of the acquisition programs and in terms of relations with industry. He said: ... we see it largely as a task for the private sector to determine how they will structure themselves to supply our needs. Competition for Defence business encourages not only engineering excellence but also innovative investment, calculated risk taking, and more sophisticated arrangements for out sourcing and finance. The record of Government ownership of defence industries around the world shows that public sector ownership is not an efficient way to buy equipment. We also await the results, particularly, of the Australian Defence Industries sale and what that may bring, both for AD! and indeed for the nation. He talked about science and technology initiatives and facilities initiatives. In tenns of this Appropriation Bill (No.3), he talked about logistic support. He said: Currently. over 21,000 uniformed and civilian personnel work providing logistics and administrative support at a cost of some $3.5 billion a year. He talked in some detail about the creation of a joint support command and some measures taken in tenns of the improvement of knowledge regarding what inventories the Defence Force needs to hold and what is actually in stock. He also talked about personnel management measures and the personnel executive. I hope, from a personal viewpoint, that there will be some further rationalisation as the reform program proceeds, particularly in tenns of training and education, where I think there is more scope for rationalisation and, therefore, savings. He finished by talking about the management of information, information system management and an administrative support executive. The upshot of all that was that we will find one-off savings of over $500 million from the rationalisation of defence facilities and stockholdings, mature annual savings of over $700 million, and targeted annual savings of $1,000 million or 10 per cent of total expenditure. The bulk of the savings will be achieved over four years from the elimination of duplication; a reduction, unfortunately, of 4,700 or eight per cent of military positions; a reduction of 3,100 or 15 per cent of civilian positions; and a further 12,900 positions to be subject to market testing. There are a number of other initiatives that I do not have time to go into. That leads me to the final point in terms of logistics-the report from the Auditor-General, Audit Report No.5, which was tabled last month, in which there was some substantial criticism of the performance management of the defence industry. I will quote one or two excerpts from the brief overview, in which it is stated: The current Defence inventory of spares, consumables and repairable items (excluding explosive ordnance) is valued at approximately $3.9b, with $lb expended annually on further procurement and the maintenance of repairable items by external contractors. Defence holds stocks of these items primarily to ensure their availability in support of ADF requirements. In some cases, this has meant procurement of sufficient stocks to maintain equipment to the end of its forecast working life. Retirement of equipment by other countries has also created opportunities to purchase bulk stores at low cost. Referring to the DER, the defence efficiency review, it said: The Defence Efficiency Review (DER) highlighted that there are significant opportunities to improve the management of Defence inventory. The DER logistic review team concluded that current levels of operating stocks are far too high. This was con.sidered to reflect a 'just in case' cultureas distinct from 'just in time'which had been exacerbated by a poor, disjointed and unresponsive distribution system. It went on to say: Defence has now embarked on the Defence Reform Programthe DRP that I have just referred toon the basis of the DER findings and recommendations. This includes a strategic logistics planning process. The ANAO considers that an important element in the implementation of that planning would be an effective performance management strategy and framework that enables both its effectiveness and efficiency to be measured and to be managed. The absence of such a framework has contributed to many of the inefficiencies in inventory management identified by the DER. It went on to say: In summary, the ANAO found that, despite increased focus in this area in recent years, performance management practices used in regard to the Defence supply chain do not reflect best practice. That concerns me, of course, because before I came into the parliament I was the Director General of Supply within navy. The audit report continues: As a result, managers are not provided with adequate information or incentives to ensure decisions are based upon consideration of the efficiency and effectiveness of the total supply' chain. It ended by saying: The ANAO estimated that even a five per cent reduction in the current stock levels of spares, consumables and repairable items could yield annual savings in inventory carrying costs of at least $23m and a potential one-time capital release of $197m. In the ANAO's view, this is the minimum possible outcome thilt could be delivered. It then makes those firm recommendations. I understand that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts will automatically look at this report and report back to the parliament and to ministers. I feel sure that the Minister for Defence would see this as a positive step forward-a critical but nevertheless positive step forward-in optimising our defence budgetary output. I commend the ministers, including the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, Mrs Bishop, for the initiatives in these areas. I look forward to the initiatives being proven over the next 12 months to two to three years. I commend these bills to the House.

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: The appropriation legislation before the House today presents us with an opportunity to discuss matters of major national importance. Before I discuss the matter that I particularly want to refer to, I point out that we have sat through weeks and weeks of government blustering and high-wire performances. We have got a Treasurer (Mr Costello) who claims the credit for low inflation and low interest rates. We have had this absolute nonsense about deficits and the whole spectre of fearmongering which has done enormous damage to our economy in terms of public confidence. While all this has been going on, while that charade has been played out, the government has been presiding over a m.ajor national disaster. It does not even know It to date, despite the fact that it has had a report on the matter for more than two months. I am referring, Mr Deputy Speaker, to our exports of iron ore, iron and steel. You will recall that this matter was discussed in the parliament last year and there has been an ongoing discussion about that matter. The government's response to this, as to so many other matters, is that it is none of its business; that the government has no real role in iron ore exports-whether we export metal or ore or whether we do it or someone else does it. That attitude has been so transparent that it is now obvious. Back in mid-September, the member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) presented to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) a report on the Australian iron and steel industry by an ad hoc committee which comprised members from both sides of parliament. It is a very useful report, even though some of us disagree with many parts of it, because it represents the first full lation of the activities of the Australian iron and steel industry, as well as putting the matter in an international context. When the report was put forward, there was a request to the minister for it to be tabled in this place so that it would become the property of the parliament, which would allow all of us to debate those issues contained within it. It is now two months later. I wrote to the minister again last week, asking him whether he was going to table it and, to date, I am still awaiting an answer. The fact is that for two months he has had a report on a major national issue which he has chosen not to bring to the parliament and, what is more, he has not responded to it, either. There has been no comment from the minister; even though he made it available publicly, there has been no government response. We are talking about an industry which is of major consequence. In speaking to the report, I point out that the committee was not a parliamentary committee, therefore it had no resources. We are appreciative of the fact that departmental staff did provide some back-up, and that was extremely helpful. I personally made a request, as did the parliamentary committee back in September last year, to the minister for a parliamentary inquiry. That was refused. The government refused to allow us to conduct a normal parliamentary inquiry and we ended up instead with a watered down version of a committee of parliamentarians, which lacked both the resources and the authority to conduct a full-scale inquiry. Despite that, some members of the committee worked very hard. I appreciate the efforts of the chairman, the member for Wannon. In recent weeks, we have seen letters to the local media in the Hunter from the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin), claiming what a wonderful report it is. Unfortunately, the member for Paterson did not attend the last four meetings; in fact, he never got involved in the report discussion at all. I think he is becoming known as the 'fatuous phantom for Paterson' because with regard to the committees he is involved in-small business, iron and steel-he did not bother to compi- show up for most of the meetings. That is rather unfortunate. The report went to the minister, and in the report a number of things are obvious. Firstly, there is the fact that we, as a country, export 130 million tonnes of iron ore a year at an average price of $23 a tonne. We earn .$3 billion a year exporting iron ore. If that was all converted to steel and exported as steel, it would earn $36 billion a year. In other words, there is a $33 billion gap between our ore exports and what we would earn if we were exporting metal. For many of us, that gap has been an issue of major concern for a long time. We see that gap as being resolvable. Aspects of the national balance of payments, aspects of massive national unemployment, would be dramatically addressed by that shift. The report goes to those issues. The unfortunate part about the report in that context is that government members felt constrained by their ideology, if you like, or by government policy of non-intervention, so that the formal recommendations of the committee are very bland. Mind you, they were actionable. Right now, for example, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) could be taking up these matters. I refer, for example, to the recommendation about barriers to exports from Australia. Of course, the country with the worse barriers is America. The fact that companies in America are taking anti-dumping action against BHP has wiped out current steel exports to that country. The government, today at APEC, could be arguing with the Americans, both publicly and privately, about their barriers to our exports to their country. The fact that we are not doing so is indicative of the lack of genuine concern by this government on things that really matter. We hear a lot of bluster about our so-called deficit. We hear a lot of claiming of credit for low inflation and low interest, but where there is a report from their own members regarding a matter on which they could take some action-particularly, for example, the anti-dumping action by Americans against BHPthere is not a word, not a murmur. The fact is that the main recommendations are bland and non-specific. There is a minority report which goes into the iron and steel industry in much more detail, and the issues that confronted BHP both back in 1995 and now. What we have seen in the last eight months is a national disaster. Our biggest and strongest company is melting down in a major way. More importantly, our prospects for exporting more metal rather than ore have evaporated. The report is potentially misleading in that it confuses iron and steel, but the fact is that minority report does point out how that occurred. The issues that are before this parliament and this government with regard to employment, economic growth and the balance of payments could all be very largely affected if we could add more value to our iron ore exports. For all of us, it should be a matter of major priority. The government's failure to table the report, to respond to the report or even to discuss it publicly in any forum, including APEC, indicate to all of us that this government neither understands the problem nor is prepared to even address it. Mr Speaker, I will resume my comments later. In the meantime, I urge all parliamentarians to ask the minister for a copy of this report, and to read it. It is a major matter of concern for this parliament.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS
text: Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order lOlA. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed. NA Nursing Homes

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. Minister, after your aged care sector meeting on 13 November, you invited nursing home providers to provide you with information supporting their needs for additional capital funding beyond that generated by the annual fee, even though you were 'not yet convinced that additional money is required'. Minister, does your most recent media release mean that you are now convinced that the $12 a day will generate all the capital providers require?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I indeed have indicated that the arrangements that I put in place on 6 November generate a level of capital that I believe will substantially address the needs for capital in the sector, and I have left the door open for the sector to give me more information, which they have not yet been able to do. I find it interesting that you should be the asking this question. This question comes from an opposition that did nothing about the capital needs of the sector. You actually oversaw a decline in the capital provided to the sector. You were the ones who did nothing for four years. Mr Beazley interjecting

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: You were the finance minister. You received advice from Professor Gregory that there was a crisis and a shortfall in capital and you did nothing about it. We put in place a policy to deal with this issue. On 5 November we announced that we were varying that policy, and I announced the new arrangements on 6 November. They are in place, and the sector appreciate the fact that they were put in place the day after the Prime Minister's announcement. I have offered them the opportunity to provide more information to me, and I will welcome that further information. They wanted time to gather that information, partly because the certification process-which is the assessment of the building levels within the nursing homes-has now obviously called into question some of the original Gregory estimates which are now four years old. Native Title

Speaker: Mr WAKELIN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. How does the government's 1O-point plan restore certainty for farmers and pastoralists holding pastoral leasehold property across Australia? What would be the implications for Australians, especially those in rural areas, if this 1O-point plan fails to gain the assent of parliament and become law?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. I preface my remarks by saying that, with some 650 unresolved claims out there, just one has been resolved at a cost in excess of $200 million. There is a degree of uncertainty of a sort that can only be appreciated by the pastoralistsand, for that matter, the miners-who live out there producing wealth, export dollars and jobs for so many Australians. Many of those people face not just a claim but multiple claims. They have no idea what the outcome might be. They do not even have an idea as to when they might know what the outcome might be. It really gets pretty demotivating to face not just the harshness of the environment and the economic stress that many people in the more remote parts of this country face but also, I have to say, the real lack of understanding of some of the armchair critics around the place, very few of whom face any of the uncertainty or the dislocation themselves, and many of whom reassured pastoralists, until quite recently, that the of a lease extinguished native title. It has to be said that it is very easy for critics to attempt to label legislation as racist when it deals with a form of title that by definition can only be held by one racial group. The original Native Title Act was subject to the very same criticism, and that ought to be remembered. The originallegislation was subject to the very same charge, the very same criticism. The fact of the matter, though, is that we are respecting the principles laid down in the Mabo and Wik decisions, and we are not removing common law rights from indigenous Australians. We acknowledge the existence of native title. In broad terms the bill will, amongst other things, achieve these objectives: firstly, it will confirm that native title on freehold, residential and commercial land and on some agricultural leases is extinguished; secondly, it will confirm that the rights of pastoral leaseholders will prevail over those of native title holders; thirdly, it will ensure that pastoralists will be able to carry out any primary production activities permitted under their leases or under government permit, regulation or legislation without any right to negotiate; and, lastly, it will, regardless of any coexisting native title that might be found to exist over the land, be subject to any land management, environmental or other relevant laws and regulation .. In a very important bit of research released yesterday by the National Farmers Federation, it was found that Australians regard agriculture as the country's most important industry. In fact, farming and agriculture was regarded by 46 per cent of respondents as the most important industry in Australia, followed by tourism at 15 per cent, manufacturing at 12 per cent and mining at 10 per cent. I then considered the Morgan poll published in this week's Bulletin on this issue that we are grappling with. It found that by far the largest number of respondents-81 per centagreed with the proposition that farmers should be guaranteed that they can use the land they lease as needed. Mr Tim Fischer-The outcome we delivered.

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: That is plainly the issue outcome that the Australian people believe ought to be delivered, it is plainly the outcome that the government believes ought to be delivered and that is what our legislation will secure. Let me issue two challenges. Although the Morgan poll shows strong support for our objectives, it also shows that two-thirds of Australians do not feel that they understand the issues. Surely then contributors to this debate should accept their responsibility to ensure informed, balanced and rational dialogue. I made the comment this morning that some of those who seek to taunt supporters of our approach based on the lO-point plan are in fact in danger of doing the very thing they say would be undesirable: promoting an unhealthy racist debate in this country. Let me pose one final question. As one who represents many Aboriginal people as well as farmers, I want to ask this question: how can reconciliation, which has to involve better relationships between indigenous people and pastoralists where they live cheek by jowl in Australia's real communities, possibly be advanced in the current climate of uncertainty and animosity over this issue? I conclude by making this point: this legislation needs passing because time is not on our side. NA

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: In fact, there are considerable elements in the legislation which address the particular problem which the member for Cowan raises in respect of the Yakabindi Mine in Western Australia. I draw your attention to the statement of the President of the Business Council of Australia who said: Continuing land tenure uncertainty detracted from Australia's ability to draw much needed investment. Australia's national development will be in jeopardy until native title issues definitively and effectively resolved. I call for the early passage of the government's bill. I tell the gallery, the House and the nation that our bill is about a fair outcome. It is about allowing farmers to manage their farming lands-whether they are Aboriginal or whatever. It allows mining companies to negotiate in certain circumstances with indigenous people so that mining projects can be developed, jobs created and export efforts sustained to the world. It allows native title to be claimed on 79 per cent of the Australian landmass, no matter that the original Mabo court decision was in respect of the Murray Islands off the mainland of Australia and no matter that the Wik test decision, 4:3, was in respect of two brilliantly selected leases by Professor Reynolds. text: This is some good news. Maybe the members opposite are not aware of the member for Menzies' long standing involvement with marriage guidance and Centacare. The government is committed to ensuring that the community has reasonable access to high quality civil marriage services. As part of a review of the program, I have today released a comprehensive discussion paper covering all aspects of the civil marriage celebrant program. Members would be perhaps surprised to learn of the role of civil marriage celebr-ts today. Just over 20 years ago, the concept was created. There are now some 1,700 civil marriage celebrants around Australia, far short of the number of religious marriage celebrants, who exceed 20,000 in number. Of the more than 100,000 marriages conducted each year, nearly half are now conducted by civil marriage celebrants. Couples should be confident that their wedding day will be one of the most memorable days of their lives. Those who wish to have their marriage conducted by a civil marriage celebrant should be confident that the celebrant is providing a high quality service which meets the couple's needs. The review aims to make the program more relevant to the needs and aspirations of couples marrying and to ensure that civil marriage celebrants are thoroughly professional, sensitive to the wishes and needs of their clients, and committed to marrying couples with dignity. The discussion paper covers matters such as ethics, a code of conduct for civil marriage celebrants, service standards, professional development, training, fees, advertising standards and legal matters. Once the review is completed and implemented, civil marriage celebrants will have an integrated policy framework and clear guidelines within which to operate. Couples in the community, irrespective of where they live , will have access to a choice of high quality civil marriage services. This initiative is a further demonstraWhat tion of the government's determination to uphold and enhance the institution of marriage in Australia.
