text: My question is, directed to the Minister for Industry, Science,. and Tourism. Is the minister aware that Commonwealth government expenditure on information technology has declined sharply by about $100 million over the last 12' months, with Australian companies especially hard hit and local jobs placed at risk? What steps will you now take to ensure that the government's outsourcing program is restructured to give Australian companies a realistic chance to bid as principal contractors, thereby' helping to reverse our growing deficit in IT? Do you have an industry policy to promote our domestic IT and telecommunications' industries or is your government's onlyinitiative the outsourcing of all government IT' services to overseas multinationals?

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: --,As the Minister for Finance and Administration, I welcome the opportunity to respond to the nonsense that was just put into that question by the honourable member opposite. The question was: what is this government doing in respect of promoting Australian industry in the information technology area? The government indicated some time ago that we were going to outsource, information technology on a whole of government basis subject to market testing. There have been some clusters that have:' been put together. By the end of this week; the first cluster will receive tenders frdin' various people who are capable of delivering the services and complying with the criteria within all the documents that have been put, out for tender. Can I indicate to the honour-, able member what those criteria are. They' very much centre on supporting Australian business, particularly small and medium enterprises. Mr Beazley interjecting

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: You can do all the ranting and raving you like, but I am going to give you this answer. For once you might like to have a little listen to it, because it is about supporting Australian business. If you do not want to hear it, just keep babbling. The criteria will indicate very clearly that the multinationals are welcome, if they wish, to tender for this work. But they must do so by showing who their partners are. Those partners must be small and medium enterprise Australian companies. They must show what content, in terms of the hardware, is Australian produced. That is also about supporting Australian business. They must show what other work they will do for Australians in Australia outside of the government contract-not just work for the government but also work in other parts of Australia-as a consortium. On top of that, they must show where they will do work as a consortiumthat is, the multinationals with small and medium sized businesses---outside of Australia. It is about growing this industry, which has growth built into it. They must show what they will do for regional development. We know that, down in Launceston, if you wish to book a ticket on an Ansett flight, you speak to someone in Launceston. Two hundred people are down there at that call centre. They take the calls from all around Australia. Call centres and databases can be located anywhere. They need not be in the capital cities. We are interested in seeing regional development. As a government, we will promote regional development. What the outsourcing will do for government, through its purchasing power, is provide savings. I can say that we are on target. All the indications are there over the sevenyear contract to save $1 billion in respect of outsourcing. We are about growing the industry by the criteria I have indicated. We are about supporting small and medium Australian enterprises in the course of seeing this growth industry develop over the next several years. The jobs will grow significantly in this area. The government's purchasing power will also assist it. So do not come in here with rubbish about our not supporting small, medium or any Australian businesses. We as a government are demonstrating that very much. When these contracts are signed, it will be there for all to see. Overseas Trained Doctors

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can the minister inform the House of the procedures by which doctors from overseas are accredited to practise medicine in Australia? Can he assure the House that the current high standards of Australian medical care will continue?

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. At the moment there are a number of overseas trained medical practitioners undergoing a hunger strike in Sydney. I think it is relevant that I inform the House what the procedures are and what the situation is. First, it is my view that people who come from overseas who wish to have their qualifications assessed should be able to have that done on a completely nondiscriminatory basis. To this end, we as a government have not sought to reinstate the quota that used to exist on the AMC exam. We have also said that, for doctors filling country positions before they come from overseas, Australia should look to overseas trained doctors here in the first instance. We give a substantial amount of assistance to help doctors from overseas try to pass the exams. We spent $900,000 last year on 153 bridging courses that we paid for for doctors, and we spent $400,000 paying the examination fees of unemployed doctors who could not afford them. Unlike comparable countries-such as the UK, Canada or the United States-in Australia the Australian Medical Council actually publishes a booklet of test questions. However, there are countries that have a very variable pass rate in the AMC exams. Some countries, such as Hong Kong and South Korea, do very well, and that reflects the very high standards of their medical schools. Other countries, such as Colombia and EI Salvador-and Italy, for that matterdo poorly, and that reflects a different type of medical education in those countries from the situation in Australia. The whole point of the AMC exam is to make sure that people who want to practise here are safe. That was illustrated in a recent exam where, I am informed by the Australian Medical Council, a question was asked about what you would do if, 20 minutes after childbirth, a woman had a substantial postpartum bleed. Eighty per cent of the people got the answer wrong, and 56 per cent of the people gave an answer that would have killed the woman. That said, since 1990, '1,600 doctors who trained overseas have passed the AMC exams-about 220 a year-and that is an addition of about 20 per cent of the total number of doctors we graduate ourselves. So the system is a fair one, but I concede that some people have difficulties. In the end, not all medical universities overseas are the same and, as health minister, I have no intention of allowing people who are not properly trained loose on the Australian public. Speaker: Mrs GASH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for the Status of Women. Minister, with 33 per cent of women now owning and operating businesses throughout Australia, could the minister please outline what the government is doing to support women, particularly those in small business?

Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Gilmore. We know that women are strong contributors to our economy steel through their work in the small business sector. Although women are frequently partowners and partners in many of our nation's small businesses, only a small percentage of these women run the businesses in their own right. This demonstrates a clear imbalance in the number of women in key management roles. In recognition of this, the coalition government has approved $V2 million for the establishment of a business incubator. The business incubator is to be delivered through the Victorian Women's Trust. We recognise 'that small and medium enterprises are the engine room which drives the Australian economy and is a major producer of jobs, particularly for our young people. We need to take every opportunity to assist small and medium enterprises to develop in this country. Called the business matrix, the program has been designed as an incubator to nurture new businesses though the start-up period. The project will cater for 35 small businesses at any given time, and it will provide a range of services, including office space, management assistance, marketing advice, financial and legal services, and network and business mentoring. The business matrix program was launched in Victoria last Friday and it will be administered by the Victorian state office of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. This innovative project is just one example of this government's commitment to providing tangible measures.,-not just the empty rhetoric of La-or' s pathetic 1998 platform but practical, realistic measures to deliver greater equality, choice and opportunity to all Australian women. It is projects such as this that will ensure that women are also able to take full advantage of this government's policies for strong economic growth and participation in the business sector. It is measures like this that will enable women in business to prosper from responsible financial policies, low inflation and the lowest level of interest rates on small business loans in over two decades. Speaker: Mr EOIN CAMERON
Title: REFERRED TO IN THE HOUSE
text: by leave-This brief statement is from the Standing Committee of Privileges. Members will be aware that on 27 August 1997 the House agreed to a resolution establishing a framework under which citizens may apply for the publication of responses to comments made about them in the House. The main features of the framework are as follows: citizens who wish to make a response to comments made about them may make a submission to the Speaker; unless the Speaker considers that the subject is obviously trivial or that sion is frivolous, vexatious or offensive, the Speaker must refer the submission to the Committee of Privileges; the Committee of Privileges must consider the submission. The role of the committee is to recommend whether a response, in terms agreed between the person and the committee, should be published. The committee may confer with the applicant and the member involved, but it may not consider or judge the truth of any statement made in the submission or in the House. The resolution of the House sets out the key features of the mechanism, but the resolution allows the Committee of Privileges to agree on guidelines and procedures to apply to the consideration of applications. I am pleased to report to the House that, while the committee will consider each application on its merits, it has agreed to draft guidelines to apply to the consideration of applications. I ask leave to present a copy of the draft guidelines. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr EOIN CAMERON
Title: REFERRED TO IN THE HOUSE
text: No doubt, as the committee gains experience in this matter, it may find it necessary to refine and develop these guidelines further. The committee would also welcome any comments members may wish to make on the draft. I also inform the House the Mr M. Salwin of Anders, Salwin and Salwin of Melbourne has made an application for the publication of a response to a statement made in the House. The Committee has considered Mr Salwin's application and recommends that no further action be taken on the matter.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have received a letter from the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House the submis- for discussion, namely: The government's failure to develop a comprehensive industry policy which directly encourages growth in investment; exports, jobs and research and development. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The charge levelled at the government in this matter of public importance is its failure on industry policy. The consequences have been lower economic growth and fewer jobs. The culprit is the inability of the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to show any leadership, not only on this issue but on any other, and the inability of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) to win an argument unless Labor creates a sense of urgency for him. This matter of public importance is about establishing that sense of urgency on industry policy. Where did the problem begin in relation to this? Their election promise 18 months ago was to create 200,000 new jobs in manufacturing by the year 2000. They also promised not to cut research and development funding, not to cut the computer bounty and not to weaken our anti-dumping system: all of them core promises, all of them now ditched. In the first budget we saw a $4 billion cut from industry support, and manufacturing was hit particularly hard. There the programs have been cut to 20 per cent of that which prevailed when Labor was still in office. And this is the sector that they were going to make the only focus for an employment target. I challenge the minister, in his response today, to recommit their target of the 200,000 jobs in manufacturing but, more importantly, to tell us what sort of progress he has made now that this government is more than halfway through its term. We also saw in that budget assistance to exporters declining· over the period and we saw research and development assistance cut by .$500 million off the amount when Labor was in office. All of these cuts were dressed up by the minister and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in particular as an attack on 'business welfare' and that they were covering the rorts. Yet they have produced not one example of a rort associated with the programs. If the minister is still going to resort to this argument today, I challenge him yet again to just give us some examples. Your budget has also been responsible, Minister, for reducing economic growth in this country by between half a per cent and three-quarters of a per cent. That is why we have unemployment in this nation stuck at 8.4 per cent. It should have been pushing seven per cent. That was what Labor was on track to do as evidenced by the department's own analysis of Labor's program. Since August last year you have destroyed 15,000 full-time jobs-not one added but 15,000 lost. Let us have a look at the minister's record. Affectionately known in some quarters as Black Jack, the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has only had success, if we can call it that, at stopping things: for example, the tariff cuts in both auto and TCF. But who led the campaign in these areas? It was Labor in consultation with the industry. They just followed. We had to create the environment in which he got the win. The minister has not created anything new in terms of industry policy initiatives. Look at steel. Rod Cameron's research showed that the weakness of the government's response to the closure of BHP's steel plant at Newcastle was a turning point in how this government is perceived in the community. If we cannot keep the steel industry in this country, what industry can we keep, Minister? Yet you indicated again today that, despite the fact that the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) participated in the steel report, it good report and that we should read it but that he is not going to act on it. The minister is directly responsible. He was out to lunch at the time, something that he keeps confirming every time he turns up in this place. We might actually get an answer if we put question time on before lunchtime. Next week we will be changing question time to an hour later so the Prime Minister can visit his cricket match. Can we have one that starts at 10 o'clock? We might get an answer from you. Not only was he out to lunch when the BHP announcement was made; he was nowhere to be found to make a comment. When he was asked to attend a meeting in Newcastle he refused to go, saying he had too an important meeting. Do you know where he was? The opening of the Crown Casino. He was rolling the dice but gambling on the future of the Newcastle workers. They lost because of your high stakes arrogance and your incompetence. What have you done to assist the automotive industry? You have adopted Labor's plan. That is what you have done. You have done the same thing with the TCF industries. You described the decision on the tariff concession orders as 'dreadful' but would not lift a finger to change it. The government has failed to meet its election commitment to reduce the time for anti-dumping complaints from 245 days to 155 days. Instead the government called for a inquiry, resulting in the Willett report. The government has failed to implement the recommendations of that inquiry and has referred the anti-dumping issue to the Productivity Commission. As yet, the terms of reference have not even been announced. We have had another fiasco in this country. Because the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) made such a botch of scrapping the DIFF scheme, it counted against us in our international trade relations. He went to China and said to them, as part of the trade-off, 'We are now prepared to treat you as a market economy. '. Despite the fact that we produced evidence that shows there is price fixing going on in China, this government now says is a China is an open market and that we will accept fixed prices on any product that is alleged to be dumped in determining whether or not to act. This is a sham. Minister, you negotiated a $200 million deal with the pharmaceutical industry to replace our factor F'scheme. Industry welcomed the announcement, but two months later we had the budget announcement on drug pricing; The Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has been running away from that ever since because of the attack on him by the member for Dobell (Mr Lee). That has resulted in a twofold negation of the first announcement. Industry was not even consulted. The Prime Minister holds this industry up as the shining light of his new interventionist approach to industry policy, but he never satisfies the claims. He does not know what he is doing and he cannot get his ministers to act in concert. The simplest form of industry policy is to have two departments working together. This minister cannot coordinate a thing with the health minister, and that is why the industry and future investment in that industry is under threat. Now we hear that the government is going to announce its response to Mortimer. The only answer we got from the minister today in response to a whole series of questions was that he only 'anticipates' it will be Monday week. He did not say it would 'definitely' be Monday week. Isn't it funny that Monday week is the day after the House gets up? Isn't there a pattern about this? They will only announce things when they are not accountable in the parliament. Why don't you bring it down next week, Minister? Why don't you bring this great policy down? Let us try to anticipate what it will contain. As I understand the hotchpotch of measures, it will put back some of what they took out, it will reannounce measures already announced, it will set up an investment committee and trade promotion agen.cy as the chief substitute for real action and it will reannounce their automotive and TCF package. We will be very interested to see this replacement export scheme not only for the car industry but also for the textile industry. That is what your agreement promises to do. You will put a bit extra into R&D, you will introduce Labor's manufacturing in bond scheme, you will announce an investment facilitator, you will announce a list of industries that will get sectoral plans, 'you will replace some of the money cut from the export market schemes and you will re-create something approaching the DIFF scheme. However, there will be no investment fund, no targets and no restoration of the 150 per cent research and development tax concession. It will not be good enough because this government is not committed to industry policy in this country. This government believes that iridustry should be cut loose and left on its own to try to get into markets without a partnership with government. It is only Labor that is committed to developing that partnership. We have our policy out there; we announced it last week. It is built around the concept of strategic intervention, partnership, mutual obligation on the part of the corporate citizen in return for assistance and government schemes to commit to targets in exports, jobs, research and development and investment. That is what we need by way of an industry policy, but we will not get it from you. Let us look at your performance today in question time. You made a complete goose of yourself yesterday. We thought we would test you out, today to see if you could redeem anything. The minister's only answer to the first question was that he anticipates we will have an industry statement next week. The second answer was in response to a question from the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) in relation to the automotive plan and the export scheme. The minister said the scheme is complete, then he said it is well advanced and discussions are continuing. Can you make sense of that gobbledegook? Do you know what you are talking about, Minister? On the question of outworkers, you said Labor did not have a scheme in place, yet the whole question was: why did you cut Labor's scheme and still have not replaced it? How can the Labor government have been doing nothing on this, Minister, if you cancel that which we were doing? There are two APEC lists, Minister. The automotive industry is not on the' A plus list and the textiles industry is not on either of the lists. Why aren't you fast tracking these sectors? Why are you going to unilaterally expose these important sectors with us cutting tariffs in the year 2005 with no obligation on the part of our trading partners? It is a complete mockery, and that is why industry still does not have confidence in you. You could not even cope with the question on outsourcing and industry policy for IT by the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans). You flicked it to another minister, and you have policy responsibility for it. You are earning money under false pretences, Minister. You should give it back. You are interested in savings for the government so give it back, because you are doing nothing. On the steel industry, we have got the position where you found it interesting; it is a good report, but you are not going to be responding to it. They will love that in Newcastle. Black Jack at the casino, but now he is not even going to respond to the steel industry report. Then, on the issue of dumping, again he buck-passed on the basis of saying he did not have responsibility for it. I happen to have a letter here which I would like to table, if the minister will allow me. In response to a query, this is what John Moore said: I am responding as the minister for anti-dumping and countervailing policy. And yet you come into the House and say you do not have responsibility. Give the money back, because you are a joke. You are not performing for industry and you are not even keeping your side up over there. We have heard stories about you-you have got this appointment to London; the staff are moving on. We had the story the other day of Mr Abjorensen who went to a senior cabinet minister and put this proposition: 'This was arguably the worse government Australia has ever seen.' The senior minister responded, 'You're expecting an argument with a proposition like that, but you will not get it from me.' Yesterday we were in the position of the minister admitting in the parliament to being that minister, but then he wrote a letter saying that he had misconstrued it. I woke up early this morning, at a quarter to six, and there was a Fawlty Towers grab on ABC radio. For people who are Fawlty Towers fans, it was the waldorf salad grab. There was a great quote. at the end where an American tourist, having been insulted, says to Basil in frustration, 'This is the worse hotel in western Europe.' But the major, who was always sticking up for the person running his home, said, 'No, no, no, there's a worse one in Eastbourne.' Here we have that position in relation to the minister. You can almost tell the story here. The journalist says, 'Would you say that this is the worse government that Australia has every had?' And John Mooreor whoever else-replies, 'No, Billy McMahon's was worse.' You are a joke as a government. You cannot introduce any policy or any direction. We are now taking a book on how that senior minister was. I must say that you were clear favourite yesterday, but the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) is closing fast on you. There is Peter Reith. He is second or third favourite-not a bad position to be in; one back, nicely placed, ready to run. This is a government that is a shambles. It is a government that has got no leadership, no commitment to industry policy, and Australians and their jobs are suffering as a consequence. with responsibility (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: There is no doubt about it. After the editorials in the Financial Review, the next best laugh you get is from the industry spokesman for the Labor Party-the battler from Bordeaux. There he is, squawking about who has been paid too much. But he takes a long extended trip to have a look at the new French governmentfrom the Left Bank and then from the Right Bank. Then we catch the TGV down to Bordeaux, have a little bit of a look around and take in a few sights down there. No trouble. From there we go to look at the unemployment problem in Venice. We are off to Venice. We catch the Orient Express, no doubt, across to there. And then, to top it all off, we go down for a couple of days in Rome. Really, what a trip-looking at unemployment and left-wing governments. And you come back here and talk about some people putting in a long day's work. Getting up at quarter to six in the morning to watch Towers is about the size of your industry policy. It is about the size of your strategy committee too, because they really did make a bit of a boner today. They were out there having a right old go, but they failed the lot. It is no wonder, Simon, that you are saving up for Christmas. It is not far away, mate. I were you, this time. I would go to Alaska. top There are not so many wines up there, so might not be so bad for you. When the Labor Party fell out of governalmost ment, a totally disgraced government, they left this government with a deficit of $10 billion, a deficit which they claimed did not exist and which we then had to approach in the oncoming budget. They left able set of industrial relations laws. They left the lowest business investment on record and the poorest overseas perceptions of our investcircumstances, ment climate. Australia's share of world direct investment was four per cent in the 1980s; it is now less than three per cent. That is a reflection of what goes on under the Labor Party. Business expenditure on R&D as a share GDP was 25 per cent lower than the OECD average. There was an average productivity improvement of just 0.9 per cent-half the world average this century. An accelerating manufacturing trade deficit went from $7.7 billion in 1982 to $27.5 billion in 1995. It no wonder that when they left government with that record the current spokesman for industry was moved to say on Radio National on 11 August 1997, 'I think we have to admit that we didn't get it all right.' It was after came back from that trip to Bordeaux that talked about those little situations where had to admit that they did not get it all right. There is no wonder that he went to the archangel of the Labor Party, Graham huge Richardson. In the Bulletin on 17 June 1997, he said: The greatest failures of successive Labor governthat ments from 1983 to 1996 was the failure to develop a coherent industry policy. Well, hear, hear! You got that one right. When you look at the state of the nation when they fell out of government, there is no R&D programs. a wonder that there was a huge task to be done Fawlty by the government. The government has accepted that complete picture. We have turned Labor's financial deficit around. We will have halved the government debt by the year 2000. Interest rates in Australia have had five official cuts from 7.5 to five per cent. We have the lowest borrowing If costs for business for very many years. On of that, inflation in Australia is at a record it 10V\'",/making it certainly a 30-year low. Business investment shows strong growth20 per cent in the year to 30 June, 1997. The Reserve Bank, for the first time in my time as minister, has noted that growth of more than four per cent would not have a bad effect on the balance of payments or interest an unworkrates within Australia. So I welcome the opportunity, under those to look at what we have been doing in relation to industry policy in Australia. For the whole of this year, the government has had a very busy time in terms of addressing all of the matters left by the previous Labor government. At the end of this year, by the time we have the response to the of Mortimer inquiry, more will have been done on industry policy than John Button or the Labor Party ever thought of in 13 years. I am pleased this MPI was put on this afternoon because it gives me the opportunity is to look through the history book to see just what we have done this year. Let me start with the pharmaceutical industry. The pharmaceutical industry investment program was initiated-a $300 million program, not $200 he million as was suggested by the previous he speaker, the honourable member for Hothain he (Mr Crean)-to encourage investment in that area. In a world in which major pharmaceutical companies are increasingly merging, and in which there is more capital investment and a development program, it is very important that we keep our eye on research and development in this area. There is no doubt development in pharmaceuticals does lead to open-sided areas of research and· development. They are no longer concentrated in one place such as New Jersey. AllY country can attract pharmaceutical R&D with the right In response to the Productivity Commission's report, we then moved on the automotive industry. Here is another example where nothing much had been altered for many years. The Labor Party program would have run out in the year 2000, and the government decided to act decisively by deciding not to carryon the program. It had led to very significant reductions in employment, and there was huge uncertainty within the industry. They did not know what was going to happen past the year 2000. The government addressed this in its policy statement in June. trioA high priority was to ensure that the next round of major investment was carried forward into the auto industry. We did this in no small measure and got commitments from the corporations themselves to investment between now and 2005 of something like $6 billion. All the major corporations that are currently manufacturing here are committed to a new round of model development in this country. Combined with that is the huge spinoff that goes to the auto component area, which is very important indeed and certainly world class in itself. We then moved to addressing the TCF industries. This was a very difficult one indeed because of the regionality of those industries, the high levels of unemployment and because investment in that area is hard to come by. Nevertheless, in September we announced a comprehensive package in response to the Productivity Commission report. The expectations are that we will get $400 million worth of new investment between now and the year 2000 on a per annum basis. The certainty corporations get from that will enable them to develop investment programs, to get up new product and to carry out whatever amalgamations may be necessary in the future. It was very important, when we looked at what the right response would be on the TCF and auto industries, that we looked to the investment, the employment side of itMr Crean-Look to Labor.

Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: These reports were addressed by the government and, as I said, they will be publicly responded to before the end of the year. These reports are significant in themselves. The inquiries were wide ranging and came up with a number of significant recommendations. I am quite sure the industry response will blow the Labor Party away. It is a complete and comprehensive report on the whole of industry in Australia. So at the beginning of this term we had a shambles. We corrected the budget and then moved to pharmaceuticals. We then moved to the responses from the Productivity Commission in relation to both auto and TCF. We then set up a series of inquiries-Mortimer, Goldsworthy and Cutler-and their recommendations have been answered by the government. That has been a comprehensive program for the whole of the year and an outstanding achievement by the government as a whole. I want to tell the House about the three goals which all of these answers were directed towards. Firstly, there is investment. We will not get employment growth in Australia, and we will not have Australia in the competitive position we want it to be in, unless we attract significant investment to this nation. That must be the hallmark of what we want to see in the next few years. To do that we firstly addressed the fundamentals in the budget in terms of the debt and the question of industrial relations and all areas of industry. We are now moving to taxation reform. All of these will indicate positive nature of Australia for investment in the future. When you look at the last five years you will see that $40 billion of foreign investment has gone into South-East Asia. All of it has swum past Australia. Why? Because we have not been a competitive nation to attract that investment. Governments of the day have not gone out there and sold the story of what we have here. This government will address that problem, because without adequate investment you will not have the necessary record to build on. Secondly, there is research and development, the most significant driving force in Australian industry. You must have research and development and innovation for the future. As a consequence of that, we wiped out the Simon Crean rorts for all his mates, all the rorts around the placeMr Crean-Name one.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The research and development tax concession for profitable companies is a 125 per cent tax deduction for moneys spent on research and development. On top of that, we began the START program of some $520 million over four years to give direct encouragement to non-profitable companies. On top of that, we introduced the Innovation Investment Fund. This concept enables private money raised by the private sector to be managed by the private sector and to be the applied to research and development identified by the private sector. With the agreement of the research and development board, they will receive a two for one top-up in terms of a loan over a 10-year period. One of the big failures of research and development in this nation has been the inability ,to carry through with the development of significant research. Far too much of that has been vacuumed out of Australia to foreign corporations or simply left not to be processed. As a consequence of that, these funds are there to pick up the research and development which has been so successful. I hope in the future we will see far greater outcomes in this particular area. Innovation in itself is extraordinarily important. We will not be able to meet the competition in 2010 if we do not spur on commitment to innovation in all forms of business in Australia, be it primary, secondary or in the service sectors. As a consequence of that, these innovation funds will be used in a number of sectors in the future to develop those particular aspects. Thirdly, we must have access to market. With the best research and development, with the best investment programs, with the best set of taxation reforms, with the best macroeconomic settings, you cannot succeed unless you have the ability to sell into other markets. Because of that the Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) and I have been very involyed in getting together programs which coordinate industry in Australia with trade outside Australia. One significant development there was in response to the TCF and the automotive industries-(Time expired)

Speaker: Mr SERCOMBE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: There was a fair bit of banter earlier in the debate about Fawlty Towers. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) tends to remind me more of that John Cleese character out of the Ministry of Silly Walks. The problem is that Australia and Australians cannot afford the sort of incompetence that this government, particularly this minister, shows in such a critical area for Australia's future. We are talking here about investment. We are talking about jobs. We are talking about our trade deficit. Regrettably, this incompetence of the government just keeps coming through. We keep getting press coverage such as a headline in the Age business section: 'Business chiefs hit Howard's industry policy'. The article states: Australia's leading business group yesterday denounced the Howard Government as lacking both a broad national vision and any strategic policy for industry. These blokes are not exactly red raggers; they are the leading business people of Australia who are saying that this minister and this government are simply incompetent. They have to be dragged to make every decision they have made with respect to industry policy. I suppose the classic case was the example of Prime Minister (Mr Howard) sitting in his bunker the night before he made the government's announcement with respect to the automotive industry umming and ahing and finally coming out of his bunker. He had to be dragged screaming to make the right decision for Australian industry. That sort of pattern still goes on. It is Labor that is providing the lead on the vital issue of ensuring that this country has appropriate anti-dumping legislation. We have heard the minister's corny efforts to avoid debate in this parliament on the crucial Mortimer report. It simply goes on. ANOP research services in August produced a report of their survey of Australian attitudes to industry policy. They characterise it as follows: There is a prevailing mood of uncertainty, despondency and apprehension in the community-a strong feeling that Australia has currently lost its way and left its potential unfulfilled. The report goes on: The implications of the despondent mood in mid 1997 are that the community knows something is amiss-and will respond to sensible, practical and constructive ideas. There is a strong belief that government and business should be acting in concert to address the community's concerns. It goes· on: The community perceives a clear lack of leadership and direction, and it believes the government has a role to play in revitalising manufacturing industry. This is the view of the Australian community. This is a set of views that the government simply do not adequately respond to. We have seen them being dragged along all the way. We have seen them dragged on reversing the ship and book bounties. We have seen them dragged on the automotive industry and also on the TCF industry. They do not seem to have understood that what Labor has been about in both government and opposition with respect to those industries is not some sort of MCEwen style protectionism; what we have been about is creating an Australian industry that is internationally competitive and export oriented. That is why under our policy Toyota invested at Altona. That is why the TCF industry almost incredibly, if one looked at it 10 years ago, is exporting $1 billion worth of Australian products and it is an industry committed to a target of $3Y2 billion of exports within the next decade. That is why companies like Churinga Designs, one of Australia's fastest growing companies according to BRW, derives something like 40 per cent of its total profit from export. That was inconceivable up until fairly recently for an Australian TCF company. That is why companies like Bradmill, which is located in my part of Melbourne in the western suburbs, are so concerned about this government's failure to recognise the importance to them of the import credit scheme. Bradmill is saying, 'The import credit scheme has allowed us to commit millions of dollars to our position as an important Australian manufacturer. The downgrading of the ICS and its eventual abolition is affecting us right now. We're facing the end of our ability to continue at the same scale and imagine further growth here.' Mr Crean-There is no answer from the minister.

Speaker: Mr SERCOMBE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Mortimer stressed, as has the minister, the importance of investment. In looking at the position the government takes on investment, I quote a recent report prepared by the Metal Trades Industry Association that quotes Chris Dixon, the managing director of a company called Containers Packaging. He says: Our experience in investing overseas really makes us question Australia's whole process for winning and assisting the establishment of new investment. We've just set up a new plant in Virginia-the speed of approvals, the level of incentives and the overall efficiency of the process far outclassed anything we've experienced in Australia. It gives me no pleasure at all to read that sort of comment in the Australian parliament, but that is what important Australian companies and important Australian industry associations are saying about the way in which this government presently operates in terms of facilitating investment. I have referred to the importance of creating the investment and the decisions that have been taken in the TCF and auto industries, but there are a whole range of other areas in which Labor is committed to developing strategic action plans: pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, medical and scientific instruments, information technology, telecommunications, metal production and fabrication, advanced manufacturing technology, shipbuilding, resource processing and environmental technology. These are crucial industries of the future that we do not hear anything about from this government. What we do hear, however, is the government talking up the possibility of a race based election. If one wanted to think of a scenario that is going to be massively damaging to this country in terms of its capacity to attract overseas investment, if one wanted to see something that damaged the social and economic stability of this country even more, one would have to go a long way to beat a government that is talking up the prospect of a double dissolution election on race issues. The minister also talked about innovation, as of course does the Mortimer report. The Melbourne Centre for Strategic Economic Studies makes it quite clear that Australia has strong competitive strengths in R&D. It is a much cheaper place to do R&D than places like Japan and Germany. Yet industrial research and development over the next two years is going to fall from $820 million to $286 million. This is at a time when the best part of $1 billion is being cut out of this nation's higher education budget, which decreases our capacity to sustain the clever nation that is required to create that innovation. In terms of exports, which is another important area the minister and Mortimer refer to, we have a situation where the government is chopping back the export market development grants. It is clearly failing to understand says: the importance of setting a direction and creating the partnerships that are needed to ensure successful manufacturing exports. Manufacturing, particularly elaborately transformed manufactures, is the fastest growing area of international trade. The government is failing in all these areas. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: If there is one area that .has distinguished the coalition from the Labor Party over the years, it has been the Labor Party's inability to understand how business works, what it wants and how to nurture it. They have absolutely no concept whatsoever. The concluding remarks of the previous speaker, the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe), highlighted that when he raised the matter of Wik. If they want·to get business rolling in this country, they would pass that piece of legislation through the Senate tonight. In my electorate alone I have 40 projects held up because of this intransigence of the Labor Party. I will just mention one. An emu abattoir is waiting to be built in Cobar with 100 jobs going on it and this opposition is holding it up. If they passed it tonight, it could be under way tomorrow. If you go and talk to the Mayor of Cobar, a previous Labor voter on some occasions, you will get the full story of how vehemently people feel because of this anti-business policy that the Labor Party continues to rtin in this country. The wording of this matter of public importance we are debating here today is quite bizarre. We do have a comprehensive policy. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) has done a magnificent job. The policy is in place and working well. I looked up the Internet site for the British Department of Trade and Industry, and under the heading 'Australia' it says: There has never been a better time to do business in Australia. That sort of encapsulates what other countries think of us now that we have a coalition government in this country. If you take the 13-year record of the opposition, there is no better quote than that of Graham Richardson in the Bulletin of 17 June this year where he The greatest failure of successive Labor governments from 1983 to 1996 was the failure to develop a coherent industry policy. That was their greatest failure, and the top guru number counter in the Labor Party admits that now that he is out of politics. It is a pretty damning statement indeed. Who is leading the industry policy in this country now for the opposition? The shadow minister was described by one Labor unity faction supporter in the 25 July edition of the Republican this year as an empty suit, someone who will argue anything. That just about sums it up in this country. Everything they did over the last 13 years was anti-business. They had no more damaging a policy than the one for interest rates. They were over 20 per cent, record levels for record periods of time leading to record bankruptcies and enormous hardships, the legacy of which we are still feeling in small and large business today. Since we have been in power-18 or 20 months-there have been five cuts in interest rates, and they are down to record low levels. On top of that, they had record debt. Their overseas debt when they were in power rose from $23 billion, which was high enough, to over $180 billion because business in this country, starved of capital, was forced to borrow offshore. As we heard the Treasurer (Mr Costello) tell the House this week, in the last five years they were in power, the Commonwealth debt rose from $16 billion to in excess of $90 billion with no plan to stabilise that debt at all, let alone pay it back-a shocking indictment. We are left with the legacy of paying the interest on that-$9.4 billion of interest every year. As the Treasurer said, if we did not have to pay off Labor's interest bill which they left us, we could abolish payroll tax in this country-and you could imagine what that would do for industry, how it would stimulate it. We could abolish the fuel excise. The people of Australia could be buying their petrol and diesel for 40c a litre if we did not have to the interest debt that Labor left us, most of which goes to overseas countries. Alternatively, we could have the company tax in this country. That, more than anything else, would give industry in this country a tremendous boost. On top of that, they left us a $10 billion budget deficit, which we have just about paid off-we will move into surplus next year. It is interesting to contemplate what is happening to our north, where we send two-thirds of our exports. There are economic bushfires raging all over Asia at the moment which, hopefully, we will be able to put out. But, if we had continued to pursue Labor's irresponsible business industry and financial policies in this country, we would probably have the IMF knocking on our door today. Mr Crean-Oh, come on! Mr Bevis-What!

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: He roles his eyes, having left us with an overseas debt of $180 billion, more than half of which is Commonwealth debt, and a budget deficit of over $10 billion, and he says, 'Oh, what!' They think this is boring, or they think it is inconsequential. I have just explained to him how we are paying $9.4 billion in this country to pay your interest bill. We have to suffer. Taxpayers of Australia have to suffer paying your interest bill when we could be halving company tax, abolishing fuel excise or abolishing payroll tax in this country if we did not have your legacy, and he says, 'Oh, what!' This is the culture that they have built up in this country today. We in Australia are proud that we lead the world in sport. We are No.1 in cricket. We are No. 1 in certain areas of athletics. We are No.1 in some codes of football. But, when it comes to industry, when it comes to productivity, when it comes to business, we are running almost last in the world of OECD countries. While the rest of the world is out there breaking four minutes for the mile, our best athletes are barely struggling over the tape in business in six minutes for the mile. That is what we have in this country, and that is what we have to tum around. While you pay maintain those sorts of attitudes, even in opposition, it is going to be harder to fix. Look at the fair trading policy that we have brought down. You had 17 reports of one kind or another on it, and what did you do? Absolutely nothing. We came into power and zilch had been done in this area. Small business was crying out for relief, for something to be done. We had one report and we implemented the lot, every recommendation in the report. We even went further. That is the sort of thing that the coalition is doing and has done in its first 18 months in government. All you did while you were there was create new taxes and put up taxes., You introduced a capital gains tax. You introduced a fringe benefits tax. You shoved provisional tax through the roof. Since we have been here we have reduced provisional tax and we have given capital gains tax relief to business, particularly small business. They can roll over the first $5 million when they sell their business and, when they leave their business, each, taxpayer can take half a million dollars wIth them capital gains tax free. We have also given relief in the area of fringe benefits We heard today from the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, who is at the table, about your steel plan. It delivered not one dollar for Newcastle. The few plans that you had in place were totally and absolutely ineffective and have failed. That is why Newcastle is in the trouble that it is in today. There was probably no worse area for business in this country than that of industrial relations. You left a legacy there which has slaughtered business in this country. It has been up to us to abolish secondary boycotts in this country because it was you who abolished sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. We have also had to change the unfair dismissal laws in this country. Even in the short time that we have been in power we have seen the claims for unfair dismissals fall by more than half. If you would support us in the Senate, we could go even further in this area, particularly for small business. But your reaction to this is to oppose it outright-'To hell with small business' - because you do not care about them. You are just on some ideological kick, taking your instructions from the ACTU, from whence you came in the first place. The policy you released the other day is nothing less than jargonistic cliches which nobody can understand. You stand condemned for the policy you have brought out. (Time expired)
