Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Title: CHEMICAL WEAPONS
text: Moncrieff-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs) (4.02 p.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The Chemical Weapons (prohibition) Amendment Bill 1997 amends the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994 in order to tax. implement refinements to the administration of that act to rectify certain problems identified during its initial implementation. The Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act gives effect to Australia's obligations as a party to the Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production and Stockpiling and Use of Chemical Weapons and on their Destruction, usually referred to as the Chemical Weapons Convention. The convention bans the development, production, acquisition, stockpiling, retention, transfer and use of chemical weapons and provides for the destruction of all existing stocks of chemical weapons. Australia has long supported the Chemical Weapons Convention as a key international instrument in the fight against the spread of weapons of mass destruction and was the sixth country to ratify it on 6 May 1994, following the passage of the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act three months earlier. Three years later, on 29 April of this year, the convention entered into force and less than 27 days later Australia's initial declarations were submitted to the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons. The Chemical Weapons Convention requires Australia to make regular declarations concerning activities with chemicals listed in its schedules and activities producing discrete organic chemicals. The Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act allows the Chemical Weapons Convention Office in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to collect, through a system of permits and notifications, from chemical facility operators the information required to compile these declarations. 1997 National inspectors appointed under the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act have the power to inspect chemical facilities to ensure compliance with obligations imposed by the act. Certain facilities are also subject to inspection by the Technical Secretariat of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons. The task of preparing Australia's initial declarations has highlighted some aspects of the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act, which needs to be refined in order to simplify its overall administration, to promote compliance with it and to ensure more effective fulfilment of Australia's commitments under the Chemical Weapons Convention. A key element of this amending bill is the provision it makes to automate the annual permit renewal process in the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act. This will simplify the compliance obligations for each company or organisation requiring a permit, but maintain the annual reporting cycle that is needed to fulfil our convention obligations. Simplification of compliance obligations should reduce the possibility of inadvertent breach of the act. It will also provide for continuity in the relationship of each permit holder with the Chemical Weapons Convention Office. This bill also provides for clarifications of some outstanding technical issues to be implemented through regulations under the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act. The Chemical Weapons Convention is a complex instrument and a number of technical issues related to its implementation remain unresolved internationally. Some of these issues bear directly on which industrial facilities should be subject to declaration and inspection requirements. Understandings clarifying these issues are expected to be reached by the organs of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons. The bill also includes amendments which refine its secrecy provisions, streamline certain administrative procedures and provide for applications, notices or reports to be made by way of electronic lodgement. To reinforce the effectiveness of Australia's compliance with the Chemical Weapons Convention, this bill also includes amendments dealing with minor drafting errors identified in the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994. Before concluding, I wish to thank all those from Australia's chemicals industry for their input with respect to this amending bill. In particular, I acknowledge the very important and useful contribution made by the Plastics and Chemicals Industries Association. Australia has been at the forefront of efforts promoting the effective implementation of the Chemical Weapons Convention. The refinements to national implementing arrangements in this bill demonstrate an ongoing commitment by the Howard government to that goal. I present the explanatory memorandum to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Bevis) adjourned. NA AMENDMENT BILL 1997 Main Committee Report Bill returned from Main Committee without amendment; certified copy presented. Ordered that the bill be taken into consideration forthwith. Bill agreed to. Third Reading Bill (on motion by Mr Ruddock)-by leave-read a third time. NA Message from the Governor General reported informing the House of assent to the following bill: Farm Household Support Amendment (Restart and Exceptional Circumstances) Bill 1997 NA AMENDMENT (YOUTH ALLOWANCE) BILL 1997 Second Reading Debate resumed from 20 November, on motion by Mr Ruddock: That the bill be now read a second time. upon which Mr Latham moved by way of amendment: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House: (1) condemns the Government for: (a) withdrawing support for 18 to 20 year aids in families with incomes as low as $23,400 per annum; and . (b) abolishing payments for 16 and 17 year olds while also slashing education funding, labour market assistance and job opportunities; and (2) calls on the Government to introduce education and training opportunities so that every young Australian has access to the education and skills needed for full workpJace and society". ; Mr CHARLES (La Trobe) (4.09 p.m.)-I am continuing. my remarks on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill, the government's proposal for a common youth allowance. During the few minutes I had available to me last week, I took the opportunity to outline the basis of the legislation and what it attempts to accomplish. I had then moved on to discuss a recent report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training which is entitled Youth employment: a working solution. The committee took some 15 months to interview and consider submissions from employers all over Australia-from employer bodies, from educational institutions, from educationalists, from parents, from business people, from ANTA and from representative bodies of the education and training industry itself. We held forums where we interviewed 303 young people-themselves involved in secondary education-who are looking forward to some future and to getting a job. One of the central themes of the common youth allowance is that we want young people to remain in formal education and/or training for as long as possible. There is a very good reason for that: Australia has an unacceptably high rate of youth unemployment. This report dealt with the other side of that equationthat is, youth employment, not unemployment-but there is no doubt that the two are interrelated. We would wish that, when every young person has received at least an initial education-in terms of literacy and numeracy, in terms of understanding society and in terms of learning how to be able to learn again in the future-they be given the opportunity to continue with that education through training courses at our institutes of TAFE or with private training providers to obtain specific skills for doing specific kinds of jobs in specific industries, or that they be given the opportunity to go on to university and to obtain a more broad based and higher level qualification which would prepare them either for some specific career or for a. broad based participation in the generalist career. It is true that entry level jobs in Australia for young people have shrunk, particularly over the last decade. One of the reasons for that is that unskilled jobs have fast been disappearing from the Australian landscape. It is appropriate that young people obtain the right kinds of skills and education before they go out to enter the formal job market itself. Not only that; they also need to approach that job market with the right kinds of attitudes. One common theme amongst the over 300 young people with whom we discussed these issues in great detail was that, if you want a job, there are jobs available. It did not necessarily mean, because they were young and they were still in secondary school, a full-time job or exactly the job that they wanted. But if you wanted to work, you had the right attitude to work, you could speak, you could write and you could read, then there were jobs available and you could get a job. It might not be exactly what you want: it might be clerking in Woolies or in Coles; it might be cleaning up in a hairdressers' salon; or it might be a skilled job at one of the MCDonald's outlets-but, nonetheless, ajob. I was highly impressed by the attitude of the young people that we talked to throughout Australia. We talked with young· people not only in the capital cities but also in the regions and in the outback-indeed, all over the country. I was very impressive by their attitude to work. Some of the recommendations that we made are perhaps appropriate to this debate on the common youth allowance. The first recommendation concerns the government's funding of labour market programs. That includes those programs which, one way or another, help find jobs for young people and pay for them to be in employment because, for some reason, they have either missed out on part of their education or they have not been able to find work for whatever reason. When labour market programs are being developed, the government should favour programs which address attitudinal and other barriers to learning and employment in individuals. That is code for saying that labour market programs need to address pre-employment training. One thing that employers all over the country told us is that the first thing they for in an individual they employ is attitude. The second, particularly with young people, is literacy and numeracy. The third, way down the list, is specific skills for the job. It is interesting that we had some debate in Victoria recently about the acceptance by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) of a training program for young people in school at the MCDonald's training facility in Melbourne. Some of the trendies thought that was pretty terrible, because they seemed to hate MCDonald's. The committee heard over and over that where an employer had a short list of potential young employees, if one of those individuals had worked at MCDonald's, the chances of that individual obtaining a full time job were greater than they were for any of the others. Why is that? Because MCDonald's gives young people personal skills and attitudes, such as how to show up for work on time, how to work with colleagues cooperatively, how to approach customers with a smile and willing service, how to produce high quality work quickly and how to be responsive to your employer's needs and the clients' needs, the ones who come into purchase. Those attitudinal skills are highly important. Another recommendation the committee made is that literacy and numeracy are of critical importance to our young people. That is another good reason for young people to stay in school. It is also a good reason for us to do a much better job in basic literacy and numeracy teaching in the very early, formative years of primary school, which are perhaps grades 1, 2 and 3. It has been recognised nationally, and absolutely accepted by everyone in the business, that if a young person has not achieved satisfactory levels of proficiency in reading, writing and maths by the time they reach age 7 or grade 3, the chances of them being kept behind in their studies, ultimately failing and winding up on the dole scrap heap, in correctional institutions or on the streets or whatever are enhanced immensely. We are saying that if we fail to teach any young child to read, write, count, add, multilook ply and divide, we have failed that child absolutely. Our recommendation is that literacy and numeracy teaching needs to be comprehensive, which means that you need to go about it every day in the early years of primary school. If that means it displaces some of the other curricula that has been crowded into primary schools, so be it; let us be done with the other curricula. There is also the quaint but important recommendation that you teach literacy in the morning, not in the afternoon after lunch when the children are sleepy and less attentive. It is the most important grounding element of their entire education program. Fancy trying to study Australian history if you cannot read. It is not difficult; it is impossible. The committee recommended another very innovative device that would go with the common youth allowance. The committee recommended that the government institute a national youth guarantee, which entitles every Australian under 21 who has not attained year 12 at school to a funded place at a high school, TAFE or a recognised training provider to complete their year 12 education or its equivalent. As I recall, the common youth allowance says that if you leave school before you are 17, the dole is no longer available. You will need to stay in school or in training. The Commonwealth, through the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation and other programs with ANTA and the state, is work.:. ing very hard to try to increase the availability of skills training in our secondary schools. That includes apprenticeship training or other kinds of skills training that will help lead young people into jobs or, if they do well enough in that extra training, get themselves back in shape to be able to study again, and then perhaps go on to T AFE courses or university at a later time. The committee believed it is important that if young people leave school early and (ind they need further training, we say to them, 'Look, as long as you undertake this work, by the time you are 21 we guarantee that you can have a funded place at TAFE, with a private training provider or back at school to get the equivalent of a year 12 education for yourself. This will help you to ultimately find a job and live a rewarding, self-satisfying and self-fulfilled life. ' The committee made a number of recommendations regarding the standards of the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation and the portability of training outcomes. In this way, young people who take a course in one location can take that qualification to another state or territory and have it recognised. People will then not look askance at the piece of paper and say, 'You're from Victoria and I'm in New South Wales, so we will not consider that piece of paper. You will have to start all over again.' Another important issue that teachers tell about is that, for some young people in secondary school, by the time they are in year 9 or year 10, the teachers know that they are likely to leave school without finishing. New programs are being developed-and the Commonwealth is beginning to fund some of those programs-to try to retain those young people who are likely to leave school without completing a year 12 qualification, with programs which are different, which will excite their imagination, keep them interested in the learning experience, and keep them in touch with formal education. Most of those programs involve some experience with real work. The student might spend one or two days a week in a real job, and the rest of the time in formal training mode within the high school. The formal training time should also, in my view, include attitudinal and pre-employment type training. At least one hour a week should be devoted to trying to impart work skills to these young people who do not have work and real life experience-whose parents may not work, and whose grandparents may have never had a job-and to teach them about the things that employers are looking for so that they can successfully take their place in the employment market. If those kinds of programs are successful, then we will not need the common youth allowance, except to the extent that it replaces Austudy. Wouldn't it be a fantastic day if the common youth allowance were about helping students with their living expenses while they are studying? That would be a terrific day, because then we would not have high youth unemployment. We would not be destroying young lives. We would not be creating a situation where future generations of young people will not thank us because they will not have the work ethic at all. The committee made a series of recommendations regarding a national youth wage. We said that it is time to do something radical, something different. While we made substantial recommendations regarding curriculum advice, which I think are perhaps the most important recommendations we made, nonetheless, it is clear that, with youth unemployus ment stuck at between 25 and 30 per cent, we need to do something radical. The coalition members of the committee believe that we ought to take youth wages out of the hands of the tribunals. We ought to take them away from the control of the unions, and we ought, by statute, to establish a system for a national Il).inimum youth wage. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION
text: I commence my address on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bi1l1997 this afternoon by complimenting the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) not just for his very fine address but for the contributionhe made to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. He has moved on to greener fields, but very few members of the parliament have shown such singular commitment not just to youth employment and youth education but, more particularly, to those aspects of youth employment and youth education which can be facilitated and improved. I have been on inquiries with him, and he is a very persistent questioner in cross-examining people on what factors really affect the educational and workplace needs of young people. Moving on to the subject of the youth allowance, one of the most demoralising things I see in my electorate is young people on Austudy or partial Austudy struggling to stay at university or TAPE, who find that down the street there is a houseful of young hoons, who are all on the dole, who sometimes might even have a swimming pool if they can get a house for the right rent, or they are spending their time on the beach, and they have a better lifestyle than the young person who is making a contribution to society and his future. That is very demoralising for that student and his parents. For someone on the margins of either studying or dropping out, the incentive not to go on and do something useful with your life becomes very attractive. To some extent, this bill tries to go to the heart of that problem. Recent statistics in the Wide Bay-Burnett area where I come from show that, with 36.6 per cent of young unemployed-that is an extraordinarily high and unacceptable figure-school leavers have never had more pressure on them to find a job which will lead them to a satisfying career. From their point of view, things look bleak unless they are better equipped. With such high unemployment in the area, there is an added incentive for young people to drop their bundle and, in doing so, drop out of school. Research shows that there was strong school retention growth during the 1980s-the percentage had risen to 77 per cent by 1992-but that last year it started to drop away again, and it was down to 71 per cent. The male dropout rate was higher than the female rate. A second reason for wanting to keep young people at school and in training is not just to keep them off the street, as the common idiom has it, but to keep them focused and motivated so that, when regions like mine go through tough times, the young people are given skills with which to advance themselves when better opportunities arrive. If you provide unemployment benefits at a higher rate than Austudy, young people are not going to want to continue their studies or further training if there is some incentive for them to drop out or if they are not achieving well at school. The students' view often is that they do not think they will get a job anyway, so why bother studying or training. Young people need skills such as computer skills for clerical work; retail training skills, as the retail trade is expanding; trade skills in plumbing, carpentry, mechanics and hospitality; and short-course skills to drive bobcats, operate cranes or whatever. Many of these courses today are delivered either at a school or at a TAPE. Many schools are now taking up these school to work opportunities. In my electorate, the first of which came from Toolooa High School in Gladstone, we even have school to apprenticeship programs. But, if you do not keep students at school for grades 11 and 12, they are never going to get that opportunity. When we were young people-there are many people of my age group in this parliamentgetting a job was not a problem. Today, young people are expected to have many more skills. Why are we replacing Austudy and unemployment benefits with a youth allowance? The government recognised there is an increasing number of young people who do not go from school straight to full-time work. Young people need to be able to make key decisions about education, training and employment without the pressure of losing financial support. Young people should complete or further their education and this bill removes the incentive to leave education early or to choose unemployment over education and training. Those young people whose circumstances change slightly will no longer have payments cancelled, thus giving them the flexibility in training and looking for work. For example, an unemployed person who undertakes training will not be required to switch to Austudy for short periods, nor will a student who drops a subject lose their entitlement altogether. This legislation also encourages those families who can to provide support to their children until they reach the age of financial independence. The member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) has said this legislation tries to defy diversity. I disagree. The legislation recognises the diversity of individuals more than the current legislation. Many young people do not find full-time work straight away; they undergo training, part-time work and more training until they find a full-time job. This legislation also recognises the discrepancies of payments between those who are studying and training, and those who are looking for work. Why should someone be paid more for looking for work than a person who is studying? That seems to me to be illogical. This is a question many young constituents and parents often ask me. I put it to the member for Werriwa: what makes looking for work more important in terms of the amount of payment than studying or training or, to put it another way, investing in your own future? The legislation goes on to recognise the diversity of the community, and the new system will not affect payments for those young people who collect Abstudy, assistance for isolated children, pensioner education supplement, disability support pension, sole parent pension, parenting allowance, the veterans' children education scheme and wage top-up agreements for apprentices and trainees. Unemployed people over 21 years of age will receive the newstart allowance, as before. If this does not recognise the diversity in the scheme in our communities, then what does? The member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) has been bleating in the chamber and in the media that the government is abolishing payments for 16and 17-year-olds, again proving Labor is equally irresponsible in opposition as it was in government. Young people aged 16 to 18 will not get the youth allowance if they are not studying or training. There is a need to encourage children to stay at school. The legislation goes on to recognise that it is not all smooth sailing for young people in those instances where young people suffer from a short-term illness, substance abuse, family problems, caring for the ill or the frail, skills. parents at home and so on. But the average 16-year-old will not be paid the common youth allowance if they are not studying or training, and I reiterate that point. The member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) has called the youth allowance an assault on Australian families. On the contrary, many Australian families will benefit from the introduction of the youth allowance, including many families in my electorate of Hinkler who send their children away to university. They will receive assistance for the first time. For others, it will be a return to parental love, guidance and-dare I say it in this chamber-discipline. Our electorate office has roughly 12 different types of computer programs which we use on a regular basis. We have word processing, databases, Internet, e-mails, spreadsheets, Pagemaker and so on. My staff are highly skilled and computer literate. They have good communication· skills with the public and senior government officials. They interact with community leaders in business and industry. That is the environment that a lot of young children will go into. If they do not stay at school and if they are not well educated, if they are-in the words of the member for La Trobe-not literate and numerate, they are going to have a very tough time of it. Keeping young people at school at 16, 17 and 18 years of age, or in training, is not a bad thing. We need to give children time to plan and to organise their lives. They need to know how to spell and to write a good letter. They need to know a bit about the world, about economics, about history, about how Australian government works, and so on. They need to know a lot about many things. While some of this knowledge is gained on the job, I could not employ a person who did not have at least some experience in computer skills and customer service. I think that is one of the reasons that at times over the years we have suggested in this place that perhaps we should have juniors in our office, but successive governments have not agreed to that. I think part of the reason for that is that, for young people to participate effectively in an electorate office, they must have those basic I do not think my office is any different from any of the small businesses across Australia. In everything today there are electronic developments and computerisation of all sorts of things from cash registers through to computing, right through to accountancy. Again, if those skills are not in place, those young people are totally disadvantaged in getting a job. I have heard it said that if a young person completes grade 12 they have a 60 per cent better chance of obtaining a job than a young person who does not. That is a very sobering thought. At the end of the day, no young person can seriously hope to drop out of school without qualifications and pick up a job, as they might have done 30 years ago. The point bears reiterating once again: young people aged 16 to 18 years of age will not be eligible for the youth allowance unless they are studying. The days of young people copping out, three or four moving into a house, living the life of Riley and going into their 20s without any experience whatsoever of work are finished. And so those sorts of things should be finished. In effect, they were holidays at taxpayers' expense. The member for Werriwa has said that we live in the 'post-traditional age of families' in order to describe the Labor Party's policy which, incidentally, contributed to the dependency on the Australian social welfare system and the taxpayer. It has robbed many young Australians of their birth right. First and foremost, we must look after our families. We must encourage families to look after their children and encourage them to achieve. When 16-year-olds drop out of school or T AFE because they do not like it and sit around watching television every day, I cannot see parents being very happy with that in the long term. It will bring home to parents, in a very forceful way, that there are other opportunities for their children. I think it will encourage parents to take up the traditional role of nurturing, caring, loving, guiding and perhaps disciplining their older children. What I can see is many parents insisting their children put themselves into a TAFE course or go back to school to get qualified and, as such, be eligible for a decent job. By encouraging families to take responsibility for their children, we put the onus of raising children in their teenage years back onto the family, but we support families giving their children focus and opportunity through the youth allowance. It is not the government's job to raise children. I have said this in relation to the changes to child care where it applies to nonworking parents, and I say it again in this instance when it comes to our older children not making an effort to find jobs or to undergo training. This legislation will benefit more people than the current legislation. It is fair, it is equitable and it gives them goals. The question that follows from this is: who benefits from this legislation? First and foremost, the whole community will benefit, including taxpayers. Seventy thousand young people who are studying or training and living away from home will get rent assistance. The average will be $31.30 a fortnight. Also, 41,200 students will benefit from the abolition of the $1,000 per annum Austudy minimum requirement. These aspects seem to have been lost on the member for Jagajaga. That does not bother me much because I know a few of my constituents will appreciate receiving even a few dollars a week to send their children to school or to university. A family living in Gin Gin, just outside Bundaberg, and sending their child to the University of Central Queensland campus in Bundaberg-a 30 minute drive--or in the Boyne Valley sending their child to the Gladstone campus of the same university, will probably appreciate $20 extra a week to encourage them and to make it easier to get their children to and from the university. Labor has forgotten how hard and how expensive it is to raise a family. So I would not expect the member for Jagajaga to appreciate how difficult it is in regional areas where the average family income is less than $20,000 a year. They are not the only ones who will benefit; 16,600 students will benefit from the independence criteria which are more lenient than those for Austudy. Fifteen thousand unemployed and 19,500 students, most of them under 18, who are living away from home and/or are independent will benefit from receiving an increased rate of payment and 9,300 continuing students aged 25 and over will benefit from the alignment of rates with the youth allowance. Thirteen thousand four hundred families of youth training allowance recipients will benefit from access to the family payment initiative. In short, lots of people will benefit. Legislation creates social expectations, and Labor's badly planned social security legislation implemented over the last 13 years has fostered, whether we like it or not, a welfare mentality. Legislation which creates a climate such as the one we have in Australia today is indefensible and this government has accepted the responsibility to change it, just like we accepted responsibility to pay back the $10.5 billion black hole debt. Do not believe young people are the little horrors the media paint them to be or that society would sometimes say they are. Most are upstanding young citizens who make an effort to contribute to the economy and to society. Many young people strive to get qualified and get a job, but the system is too forgiving on those who do not make an effort to contribute. We can attribute that to the social environment which Labor fostered, especially over the last 13 years. Finally, looking over the whole ambit of this problem, we need to get those young people in the age group of 16 to 18 years of age better equipped to compete in a much more demanding work force. On all the inquiries I have been on with the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training that have involved young people and the suitability for education, one thing has come through clearly: disadvantage can be linked to literacy and numeracy, or literacy and numeracy can be linked to disadvantage. The experts disagree with comes first, the chicken or the egg in that instance. That there is a correlation between the two things is beyond any doubt. If we extrapolate from the young people that the member for La Trobe talked about at the very critical ages of their school development out to the 16to 18-yearolds, it follows that if they are going to advantage of the new programs, the new computer skills, the school to work opportunities, the TAPE opportunities, the university opportunities that are folding out before Australians, then there must be encouragement and support. That can be found in this youth allowance.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION
text: In relation to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997, I would like to thank all the members who spoke in the debate. While I recognise the two members who have spoken here this afternoon, the debate has been a long one and many have contributed. The non-government speakers in this debate have focused on several specific issues to which I will refer. Several speakers have suggested that the requirement that a young person aged under 18 must be in education or have finished year 12 to qualify for youth allowance should be omitted from the bill and that those who have not finished year 12 should be able to enter into an activity agreement which would be included in case management. It is worth reminding the House of Labor's own rhetoric in this area. For instance, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) told the Age newspaper on 15 November that Labor would recognise the lack of entry level jobs for 16to 18-year-olds and design policy to support this group to stay in school or training. The youth allowance provides positive incentives to realise this objective while also making provision for those young people for whom education or training may not be a reasonable requirement. For instance, in cases of illness, the imminent or recent birth of a baby, living in a remote area, recent job loss, inability to seclire an appropriate education or training place, caring responsibilities, learning difficulties, major personal crises, homelessness, major disruptions to the home, substance abuse, substantial part-time study and/or workload, having been a refugee prior to claiming youth allowance, being subject to a community service juvenile justice order or some other special circumstance which may take include non-employment related case management, youth allowance will be available. Employment case management will continue to be available to young people who are not on youth allowance through FLEX, that is, flexible labour exchange services, from May 1998. It has also been claimed that the education sector will not be able to cope with the numbers of students who stay on at school or seek education or training places. The government is funding a range of innovative programs to improve education and training opportunities for young Australians, particularly in the area of vocational education and school work experience programs. Funding has been provided through a number of measures. Firstly, the Australian Student Trainee Foundation has been allocated funding of $9.9 million for each financial year for its core operations, that is, approxirecognised mately $40 million over four years. The budget also increased funding by $10 million in 1997-98 and each of the following two financial years to support workplace coordinators, that is, $30 million over three years. Secondly, the National Training Authority Ministerial Council agreed in 1996 to provide $80 million over four years-1997 to the year 2000-to state training authorities for allocation to schools for vocational education and training. Thirdly, the school to work program funded for $23 million over the four financial years 1996-97 to 1999-2000 promotes effective and reliable pathways from schooling to employment for young people. The honourable member for Jagajaga expresses concern about the extension of the parent means test under the youth allowance to unemployed customers aged 18 to 20. However, she fails to explain why it is acceptable to means test Austudy recipients but not their peers who may be unemployed. This inconsistent treatment sends the wrong message to young people that they may be better off on the dole than in education or training. For example, in a family on $30,000 per annum with an unemployed child and a student child, both aged over 18, while the student would be paid $111.60 per fortnight, the unemployed sibling would be paid $174.80 per fortnight. That difference of almost $60 a fortnight could be a persuasive argument against taking up education or training opportunities despite the obvious longer term benefits to the young person of doing so. It has been suggested that the rules for de facto couples should be aligned with those for other social security payments, so that people would not have to have been in the relationship for two years to be considered members of a couple for youth allowance independence purposes. The arrangements for members of de facto couples under youth allowance represent a compromise between arrangements under Austudy and those under other payments under the Social Security Act. Currently, de facto relationships are not recognised at all in relation to Austudy independence, whereas de facto couples are under the Social Security Act regardless of the length of the relationship, although there is no financial gain for people to present themselves as members of a couple if they are not genuinely in a relationship. The youth allowance position of recognising relationships of two years duration is a fair compromise which recognises that young people in long-term relationships should be considered independent, without providing an easy means for young people to avoid having their payments parentally means tested. Young people who are in a relationship where one or both are not considered independentfor other reasons-will not be subject to the partner income test. It has been suggested that the youth allowance should be indexed every six months, in April and September, in line with the arrangements for pensions and other social security allowances. The youth allowance indexation provisions are not in fact contained in this bill at all-they will be introduced in the forthcoming consequential amendment bill-and they therefore cannot be amended now. However, the intention is that indexation will occur once per year only, based on the June CPI, effective on 1 January each year. This is in line with current arrangements for Austudy. It is also in line with current arrangements for social security allowances for single people aged under 21. Contrary to suggestions that the latter are indexed twice yearly, in fact they are not. Clearly, it would be ludicrous to move to twice-yearly indexation when both major customer groups are currently accustomed to indexation only once a year. Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: PAIRS
text: by leave-I move: (1) Schedule 1, item 6, page 10 (line 27), omit "subsections (5) and (6)", substitute "subsection (5)". (2) Schedule 1, item 6, page 11 (line 29) to page 12 (line 16), omit subsections (5), (6) and (7), substitute: Meaning of approved course of education or study (5) For the purposes of paragraph (l)(c), the course is an approved course of education or study if it is a course that the EmployNOES ment Minister has determined, under paragraph 7(1)(c) of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973, to be: (a) a secondary course or a tertiary course; or (b) a part of a secondary course or a part of a tertiary course; for the purposes of section 7 of that Act. Note: For educational institution see subsection 23(1). (3) Schedule 1, item 6, page 28 (lines 22 to 25), omit paragraph (c), substitute: (c) the person is undertaking full-time study and is at least 25 years old. Two of the three amendments remove from the bill the authority for and all references to the secretary to the Department of Social Security being able to approve or not approve courses of education or study for the purposes of the new youth allowance. This power is to rest solely with the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. The third amendment is a technical amendment to better express the fact that the maximum age for youth allowance for a person undertaking full-time study is 25 years.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: PAIRS
text: The opposition is not inclined to oppose any of the three amendments. I will make some brief observations about them. The first is that if Minister Kemp wishes to take away from the Secretary to the Department of Social Security the approval for courses of education for the purposes of the youth allowance, the opposition will not stand in his way, although I do suggest that the minister will be creating somewhat of a rod for his back. We will be following with great interest the sort of approval and disapproval that he brings to these particular matters. I can only join with his Victorian Liberal colleagues in suggesting that, contrary to 20 or 30 years of public rhetoric, he is in fact one of the great centralists of federal government and the federal parliament. I am told that, in the Victorian Liberal Party, to call him a centralist is the greatest insult that can be levelled. I am sure to be called a centrist or a centralist is an insult in the terms and conditions of the Victorian Liberal Party. The third provision concerns the maximum age requirements for youth allowance. The amendment provides that a person simply has to be undertaking full-time study and have turned 25 to reach the maximum age. It is poor indeed for the government to be moving amendments at this late stage which deal with fundamental questions like the maximum age for qualifying for the youth allowance. This is sloppy drafting which in fact is typical of the whole bill, and the opposition expects there will need to be a raft of government amendments in the Senate to correct similar problems in other parts of the legislation. We will be watching those amendments with interest. But, as I mentioned, we are not inclined to oppose any of these three government amendments to the youth allowance bill. Amendments agreed to.
