Speaker: Mr REID
Title: TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT
text: I wish to continue from where I left off last night in the debate on the Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) is currently supporting our legislation. His support for unconscionable conduct being included in the bill is unchanged. The member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) said that the opposition would try to amend the legislation to remove unconscionable conduct from the bill. After 13 years in government, 17 reports and reviews on fair trading, the ALP have not learned any lessons about small business. There is a history of procrastination, reports, reviews, white papers, et cetera, but they still have not learned that small business wants an end to uncertainty. This bill is about a new deal and a fair deal, which is what small business wants. The evidence presented to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology inquiry further exposed the abuse of market power and unfair conduct in commercial transactions. The intent of the committee and the government was to make changes to induce behavioural change on the part of big business towards small business. By nature I am not a person of regulatory mind, but in this instance it was necessary to introduce some changes. There has been an ongoing debate on the Trade Practices Act for something approaching 20 years. By way of confirming that I am not overly regulatory, the other major inquiry I did was in 1988 in the Victorian state parliament, an inquiry into 'electricity supply and demand in Victoria intent beyond the 1990s'. That led to deregulation of the whole electricity industry in Victoria and was the forerunner to the establishment of the national south-east power grid in Australia. I want to come back to the unconscionable conduct provisions and talk about the changes to the Trade Practices Act. The government has decided to establish a new small business provision in that act, section 51AC, that builds on well understood consumer protections against unconscionable conduct to small businesses and provides further protections against the business conduct issues identified by the standing committee. It is based on established legal doctrine in that there is already a body of case law on the protections available to consumers against unconscionable conduct. The approach will also provide small businesses with the protections they need against a range of unfair business practices. The new small business provision is designed to induce behavioural change in dealings between large and small business and ensure the commercial dealings are carried out on a more equitable basis. It balances the need for fair conduct in commercial relations with the need to maintain an open market and does this without compromising the basic principles of contractual relations and commercial risk which remain at the core of our free enterprise economy. A bargain or commercial transaction will be deemed to be against conscience where one party is at a special disadvantage and the other party unconscientiously or without conscience takes advantage of the opportunity thus placed in their hands. The key is still that a party has to be in a position of special disadvantage, so the new amendment will not provide relief simply because there is some difference in the bargaining power of the parties. The new legislation goes beyond this base point, however. Our proposed section 51AC suggests the court must take a number of items into account when hearing a case of unconscionable conduct against the small business. Many of these items matched those proposed by the fair trading committee report in its suggested prohibition on unfair conduct. In fact, our provision in the government's bill is an amalgam of the factors the court may have regard to in the existing consumer provision with the final five factors of the committee's recommendations. It is set out in the bill and it goes through all of the recommendations that were contained in recommendation 6.1 of the committee's report. Clearly, these items, as spelt out in proposed subsection 51AA(2)(a), (b), (c), (d), (e), (f), (g), (i), (j), (k) and (1), are the additional provisions which the court may take into consideration in deciding unconscionable conduct. Clearly, all of those items go to the heart of the issues raised by the committee. One of the important things that I do want to mention about the work of that committee is the way the committee operated. I believe that one of the major reasons for the success of the committee in developing that report was the composition, the membership, of the committee. They had extensive experience in business both large and small but no formal legal qualifications. That was important. None of the members of that committee-I took the opportunity to check this-from either side of the House had any formal qualifications in law. So there was a very clear intent by the committee-and they did an excellent job on this report-for the recommendations to be formulated as clear statements of principle rather than formal legalese. This led to the opportunity for the bill to be introduced into the House, which makes it very clear that recommendation 6.1 has been adopted with all of those enumerated factors which I went through included in it. An important adjunct to the inquiry that we conducted is the fact that the government has taken all of those things into consideration without destroying the intent of the committee. The government's response to those recommendations subsequent to the tabling of that report included good legal advice. I wanted to mention a couple of other issues as well which relate to the matter that I just raisedthat is, the government's decision to establish a new small business provision, proposed section 51AC, in the Trade Practices Act. This particular matter had a very long history and went right back to the days of Charlie Blunt. Then there was the Beddall report and the Schacht report. In all, over the time of the previous government there were 17 matters of inquiry and no action for small business. Small business were very frustrated by the inaction of the previous government. I have taken great satisfaction from being (h), able to work with the members of that committee. They were very clear on what their intent would be. I want to particularly mention them: the members for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans), Petrie (Ms Gambaro), Lowe. (Mr Zammit), Canning (Mrs Johnston), MCEwen (Mrs Bailey), Mallee (Mr Forrest), Aston (Mr Nugent), Paterson (Mr Bob. Baldwin), Scullin (Mr Jenkins), Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), Rankin (Mr Beddall), Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) and Corio (Mr O'Connor). They did an excellent job in bringing that report to fruition. It was supported by both sides of this chamber. In conclusion, I want to place on record my thanks to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith). It is great to have a government which has small business representation in the cabinet. That has been very well received by the small business community in Australia. He is doing an excellent job. I compliment him for his open-minded approach to what appeared initially to be a very difficult task. No doubt with that open-minded approach we were able to introduce this measure which constitutes this legislation. It has been, as I indicated to the House, subject to ongoing debate for tQPre than 20 years. The legislative amendments provided in the bill are key elements of a multidimensional reform which, once implemented, will constitute a landmark change for all small business, will improve business conduct in Australia, will find a balance towards fair trading in Australian economy and, together with the government's other initiative New deal: Fair deal will encourage businesses to deal with each other fairly and reasonably. The government's framework will build a sophisticated, innovative and strategic Australian industry. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT
text: In speaking to the Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill 1997 and the amendment, I should firstly lay a few ghosts to rest. The suggestion has been coming through over and over that there were 17 reports under the previous government and that nothing was done. The Chairman of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), knows that is not true. He is very aware of that. In fact, the report goes through a lot of the changes that were made. He also quite rightly paid tribute to a number committee members who worked quite hard on this inquiry, and I agree with him on that. I note that my colleague the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) is on t1c.: speakers list. He is now becoming quite falnous as the fatuous phantom from Paterson-fatuous because he trivialises most things he touches and phantom because he does not come to committee meetings. He attended one hearing. Of all the hearings we had, he came to one only because it was held in Canberra. If you look at his record, you will see that between September last year and February this year he did not come to one meeting at all. He missed virtually all the inquiries, yet he talks about what a great report the committee he is a part of produced. Phantom because he does not turn up; fatuous because he trivialises everything he touches. The fatuous phantom will be speaking later in the debate and we look forward to his comments. Those of us in the previous government who were involved in the inquiry in 1989-90 attempted to warn current government members what to watch out for. One of the things to watch out for was the word 'unconscionable'; we had been got by it before. As the chairman of the committee well knows, the recommendations of the previous report, the the Beddall report, were not adopted but they were modified. The spirit was picked up, as we were advised by the then bureaucracy. What was asked for was not provided. What was provided was a new section on unconscionable conduct. Up until now, as the report demonstrates, that has not been able to be used. The committee very carefully, after a lot of advice and consultation, shifted to 'unfair' because 'unconscionable' does not work. It is a bit rich for the chairman to now tell us that 'unconscionable' is okay. After going through all the discussions on that word, he knew that the bipartisan agreement was that 'unconscionable' was not a goer. You have been tripped up by the bureaucracy again. And you have the gall to come in here and talk about previous governments and previous reports. That report, which was a good report, had been gutted with your approval. Do not betray your own report. We were ignorant in 1996; we did not realise the implications of it. We are not lawyers and were not able to provide a legal response to it. We were advised that the word 'unconscionable' was applicable when, in hindsight, it is clear that it was not and will not be in the future. The government's shifting of that one word is absolutely critical, as is the amendment to reinsert it. The adoption of the committee's report-the report which the chairman oversaw and spoke in favour of in the parliament when he introduced it back in May-is important. It is also important to go to the next step and to understand a couple of things. Firstly, the nature of business has been changing dramatically in Australia and in various parts of the world. Governments and communities have responded in different ways, as have the states. We have seen the contraction of the traditional small corner store and the small retailer. Corner stores are almost a thing of the past. The advent of shopping centres has been one part of it, bilt more importantly there has been a taking over by large chains of the areas of business that were normally supplied by smaller operators. An example is the expansion of Woolworths, Coles, Franklins, Bi-Lo, Jewel and the few others expanding into bakery products, confectionery and all kinds of things and opening, in some cases, for 24 hours a day seven days a week. That is changing the nature of business entirely and causing major problems, which is one of the reasons why the report recommended a national code of tenancy. Part of all of this is to do with who can sell what in what set-up. Take, for example, a butcher in a shopping centre who discovers, out of nowhere, that Woolworths is suddenly selling meat, as is Coles, in the same centre. What is more, they are open 24 hours a day and selling it for less than he buy it for. In a similar situation, a shop that sells cigarettes and gifts finds that the Coles supermarket in the centre sells cigarettes at lower price than it pays the suppliers, the manufacturers. In fact, in that one centre Garden City at Kotara in Newcastle not only did that occur but also the shopping centre management allowed in a cut price cigarette retailer. So you had what was a reasonable disaster. business at one stage being cannibalised by the introduction of a competitor on a nationsurface wide franchise buying at nation-wide levels at a much better buying price than a sale trader. Subsequently, and partly in parallel, the chains operating in the same centre were selling at a lower price as well. So what has happened to that business? That business has suffered grievously. That is the kind change that is occurring. With the report and the inquiry, we were trying to change the rules a bit to ensure the giants-whether they be the giant chains increasing or the giant managers such as Lend Lease, Westfield or AMP-were not simply consumNewcastle, ing the small traders. 'Consuming' is a appropriate word. It is not an exaggeration. the last 10 years we have seen the conversion of goodwill into rent. It was put to us very clearly that a business now has a business as long as the lease lasts. When the lease finished, you are finished. That was made absolutely clear during the inquiry. In many cases people have paid good money for a business which on the surface was excellent only to find out that after the two-, threeor four-year lease was up for walk, renewal, either they have had to pay higher rent, or rent which is not affordable, or they have had to go. Cases have been brought ,tp us. One example was given to us where. & tenant attempted to sell the business and ihbuyer disappeared, but the buyer came ba,C,1S after they closed and went into that centre., We are seeing a conversion of what w.a$ goodwill into rent. The ratio of rent to tU1l1-., over is increasing, and the figures on that .a,tt1 fairly evident. It may vary from centre to centre, but the overall trend is very clear. Within that, we are also seeing a potentiaJ' can fraudulence in the value of these centres> Again, I do not say that lightly either. If we; go to the Hansard and look at the evidence of the Australian Institute of Business Brokers a and the Institute of Valuers, we see that; iii both cases when asked if centres were overat valued, the answers were yes. In fact, th¢, Institute of Valuers was asked, 'What's gol'ng to happen? What will be the result?' The answer was, 'Armageddon.' In other words;' ': There has been a factoring in of rents at t-b level, at the gross level, into the valuation of the centres. It is distorting quite seriously the actual value, which in turn' - s, putting more pressure on centre managers and; owners to extract more and more rent. On the' one hand, we are seeing the chains sayin.g,: 'Let us sell what we like for as long as W'?: of like and for as many hours of the day we want or else we will go and open our own centres.' On the other hand, we have clauses, that and turnover figures which demand ever; profitability out of the same centre,.: For example, in Charlestown Square at we have a situation where thvery centre management and a number of the In tenants are now locked in combat in the, courts, would you believe. Tenants are paying; lawyers to fight their landlord. There are' al for few examples of this, but perhaps the most is controversial example is the attempt to con-i vert part of what would be the public spa-e, the open space, in a centre into a coUye lounge or eating area. ., In these centres, the open space, the amouof free space in which people can congregat--: and feel some sense of spaciousness,< ,i-: now being converted mto more and mor,e. - - "/I'! rentable space. The Lake Macquarie couric,i,rejected that application for 70-square metres, so Lend Lease appealed to the land and environment court. In the mediation process the council offered a smaller figure of 50square metres. It was trying to seek a solution. That has been rejected by Lend Lease and they are back in court next week, I think. Here we have the situation where tenants are paying lawyers to represent them against landlords. What kind of business are we in? What kind of mentality is it when people who have major investments for themselves and their families in these centres, and whose future depends on the success of the centres, are being forced into confrontation and legal battle with giants like Lend Lease? This did not happen last year. The events I am talking about now did not happen last year, before the inquiry, during the inquiry or four years ago. They are happening right now. Next week they will appear before an arbitrator in the land and environment court to make a judgment. The landlord versus the tenantsno-one wins. There are other parts that concern me, and this is why I think these amendments are so important. It is important that there is a national code of tenancy. It is important that there are national standards because, quite frankly, in many cases the landlords are bigger than the states. The variations from state to state have always been a problem and always will be. It will be very difficult to get a uniform code across the country. We need to have a uniform code. We are, after all, one country, not eight. The need for a national code was canvassed strongly in the report and was adopted unanimously. The fact that the government is not supporting it is a grievous weakness on its part. It has been rolled by the big end of town. The government that supports small business has been rolled by the big end of town by that part of the report, and for many people that is the only part. For many people out there, the tenancy laws are the only things that they have. That is all there is. All the is for nought. If the landlord can dictate the terms and cannot be trusted, then all the rest is· worthless. In that context I have to explain that, having now spent quite a lot of time talking with landlords and with tenants, I no longer have confidence in the management of the centres that I represent. I believe I have been misled in those situations and I believe that the tenants are not getting a fair go. I personally cannot act on their behalf unless there are laws made by this parliament to empower me and my colleagues. All of us need a federal code and federal laws so that we can make representations to federal bodies and to federal ministers. I am sick and tired of being helpless, watching things happen which are unjust and having no-one to turn to because there are no laws covering it at this level. An example of what is occurring right now happened in recent weeks. A particular tenant in Charlestown was having difficulty. The landlord was aware of that back in February or March this year. They spent a lot of time trying to improve that business and worked very hard at it. It was quite coincidental, but within a matter of days that tenant was visited by a prospective buyer who told him and his partner that, if he waited a fortnight, he would get the business for nothing, and that his fixtures and fittings were worth only $1,000that was all he would get for them.· He also had a letter from the landlord terminating his lease and a letter from his major supplier issuing a summons for unpaid accounts. So within days he had three major events. I have talked to the landlord and I have talked to his major supplier and I accept that these things may have been coincidental. But I do not accept that, between May and now, when both the landlord and the tenant were trying to get that business to become successful, there were liabilities built up. When the tenant moved out, he gave a fortnight's notice, which was incorrect. The notice was extended for four or five days, almost a week, and they were charged an extra $3,000 for those days. Having been in partnership since May, which we were all applauding, guess who rest pays the bill? The tenant was slugged for the whole lot. Those partners have no money. They have gone broke. They have had to walk out. But the landlord was getting a new tenant instantly, therefore he was not suffering. The whole mon-hs of experiment and testing were then put down to the tenant alone. When the tenant put to his various creditors a repayment schedule offering particular cents in the dollar, having lost a lot of money himself in the meantime, guess who did not agree? The landlord. That means that the landlord, who has control, effectively has the potential to bankrupt these people. And for what? They have already lost their shirts. These are people with some pride. and some dignity. They have been in a business and it failed. They have been punished more than enough. What did the landlord say to me? He said, 'I have got a duty to my trust holders.' I said, 'Your trust holders have investments in an organisation which is almost certainly overvalued. What are you doing about that?' The same management had put to me some weeks back that they would be sensitive to these people's misfortune and that they were very mindful of the circumstances. Yes, their actions were pre-emptory in the way it had been terminated and they had done things which could have been done better, if I can put it that way. When the departure occurred, the bill turned up for the full amount. Now they are settling for 50 per cent. These people have nothing. The parliament may well hear some more about those matters because, between now and when this bill finally gets dealt with, we will see case after case brought forwardwhether it be in Charlestown Square, Garden City or another centre in Australia. I am encouraging all my colleagues to keep this in mind because tenancy laws are fundamental. This government cannot walk away from the most important part of the report. The bulk of the submissions were from tenants. The bulk of witnesses were tenants in centres. The bulk of the heartbreak was suffered by tenants. The bulk of the problems in small business that we were exposed to were to do with the need for a national tenancy code. This government has done what it accuses us of doing. We may have been excused for that seven years ago because there were no examples. We put in place what the bureaucracy and the big end of town said would work. The report proves that it does not work. So what is the government doing? It is putting back unconscionable conduct, knocking out unfair trading from the report and not adopting a national tenancy code. Speaker after speaker has said how the report is being adopted in full. That is misleading-even more, it is deceitful. The report is not being adopted; bits of it are. The key part is not. Do not think this is over. Tenants out there still want a national code. Tenants out there are still suffering. They will go on suffering until we end up with a decent national system that protects people who pay rent. These people are consumers and they are entitled to some protection. They are entitled to a uniform national system because they are all Australians. I am optimistic that the Senate will agree with us and adopt the report in full. Then the onus will be on those government members to come on board and support their own report. It was a good report. Let us not undo the good work by gutting it the way the minister has. If it is fully adopted, it will work. If it is only partly adopted, this battle and these troubles will go on and on. This is the one chance that many people will have and it must not be missed. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr RICHARD EVANS
Title: TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT
text: It is a pleasure to be speaking on this very important bill, the Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill 1997. I want to cover a couple of points raised by the previous speaker, the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris). It was amazing to listen to the contributions of the first two speakers for the opposition: first, the shadow minister, the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), who spoke for some 30 minutes about retail tenancy; and then the member for Newcastle also spoke about retail tenancy. But the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and TechnoJ.ogy entitled Finding a balance is not only about retail tenancy. The problem with the Labor Party is that they have no idea about small business: they have no idea about the small manufacturing businesses, the small distribution businesses and the small franchise businesses-they are only interested in retailers and in politicising this whole particular issue. The whole question about this legislation is the difference between hardball business and unconscionable conduct. That is what this bill is all about. The previous speaker talked about retailers and how they are getting a bit stiff at the moment. One of the reasons why they are getting· stiffed at the moment is that they are not making any money at all; they are not making any profits. If they were making money and they were making profits, they certainly would not be putting submissions into an inquiry. One of the reasons retailers are putting in submissions is that their customer base has been destroyed by the policies of the previous government. That is why, in a general sense, they were forced out of their previous jobs, given big payouts by their superannuation funds and have gone into business without any advice at all. Then they expect to make a big profit, a return on investment within two years of the lease, knowing that the lease expiry was in two or three years-just silly things associated with going into business and not seeking appropriate advice. Hardball business is, in fact, legal. The area between hardball business and unconscionable conduct is grey and uncertain, which is the reason why the committee developed its report and why the government has responded on this particular issue. This piece of legislation going through at the moment is very important for small business. It will protect small businesses against the predatory conduct of those who have power above themwhether they be big business or other small businesses. This bill shows how the Howard government has acted quickly in responding to small business needs, unlike the previous speaker who suggested that we are not. We have given small business tax cuts, we have cut the red tape and we have done a lot of thingsyet business wants more from us. But what small business really needs is a bit of certainty and security of tenure. That is what a lot of small businesses do .not have at the moment under the current regime. They want to go about their business without having to worry about others impacting unfairly on their business. If you ask any small business out there at the moment, 'What does unconscionable conduct mean to you?' they would put that at No. 100 out of 100, not thinking that it is important. But it is very important, especially when they become threatened by those using hardball, unconscionable conduct against them. That is why we need this legislation. That is why the government has responded to the committee's recommendations. We are taking action on this issue-action that those opposite, when they were in power for 13 years, did not respond to after having 17 reports. In fact, in response to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Cadman) interjecting, 'It didn't happen 18 months ago, though,' the member for Cunningham said in his speech on the second reading: He is dead right. That is quite true. It did not happen. Minister Beddall, in the former Labor government, did have as an inquiry reference an examination made of the same issue. He put his recommendations forward and, as I am sure he will say in this place when he comments on this legislation, he was unhappy that the government of the day did not take them up. I regret as well and I have said that in many places. He has said many times that the previous Labor government did not bring these things forward. This government has. The Labor government promise so much: they always promise, promise and promise, but never deliver. They deliver misery. There is a lack of seriousness on this particular issue. That is why I reject totally the second reading amendments being put forward by this opposition because they just do not understand small business. They have promised much in the past and never delivered; they were always promising, yet always never delivering. The member for Cunningham admitted so in his speech on the second reading. Labor's attitude towards small business is what really motivated me into politics in the first place, which might disappoint the shadow minister, the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), who is at the table. Unfortunately, his party's policies motivated me into politics: their IR, their tax, their ance and their paperwork. Labor just demanded from small business and screwed small businesses into the ground. The reason I am in politics is their attitude towards small business. Opposition members now want to delay and stop this from happening. Looking at the speakers list for this very important piece of legislation, what do we see? We see that there is no-one on it. There are only five members of the opposition on the speakers list, including former Minister Beddall, and not one of them has small business experience. Where are they all? All 40 of them should be in here speaking on the bill and supporting their amendments. But they do not care about small business. Looking at our speakers list, we have about 20 or 30 speakers because the government cares about small business. They do not. Just a quick little reference to the Parliamentary Handbook about this: how many of the Labor Party actually come from small business?

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT
text: Tell us, come on. How many?

Speaker: Mr RICHARD EVANS
Title: TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT
text: I do not know, it was boring reading, but I think it was about one of them-in fact, none. Where was the current shadow minister, the member for Cunningham, when the Labor Party was giving us bad deficits and high debts? What was he saying to protect small business? Where was he when we had some bad recessions and weak recoveries? Where was he then, speaking up for small business? In fact, he was not speaking up for small business. Currently, Australia is committed to $9 billion a year in interest on debt which was run up by the member for Cunningham and his colleagues in the Labor Party. We have to pay $9 billion interest every year because of this party opposite that is against small business. This $9 billion bill, $9 billion of interest every year, could cut company tax in half if we did not have to pay it. It would get rid of the fuel excise tax; it would get rid of payroll tax-that tax against employmentyet Labor Party members ran up the bill. They got the interest rates going up. They do complinot care about small business. Labor Party members are not good for business, particularly small business. They are destroyers, and they want to destroy this legislation. Small business wants this legislation to go through parliament quickly, yet what do those opposite want? The previous member said that he hopes it gets delayed and amended in the Senate. That will mean a Senate committee, which means that the legislation will be delayed for at least three or four months or maybe even six months. It may not even get in before the end of this election term. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) said in a public meeting on 17 September that he would support our legislation if it reflected the report and that he would try to get it through before March. He also said that the tenancy agreements should be left to the states. That is what he said at the time. But the ALP members want to destroy this good intention. They have nothing and they will not do anything. They will say anything and they will not do anything, yet they promised everything. They said in government that Australia would continue with the process of economic reform, but now they are reversing reforms. The Labor government said in government that tariff cuts help boost exports. They are now saying the opposite. Why would they say that? Just 18 months ago, they were saying one thing and now they are saying another. The reason is that they want the vote. They want to delay this because they are going for the vote of the retail tenancies. But the retail tenancies are smarter than the Labor Party. They realise that you cannot have a Corporations Law which covers trusts in Australia. This may come as a shock. to the member for Newcastle. He must have been asleep in the inquiry when we heard evidence on this. You cannot legislate Corporations Law Oller property trusts, as those opposite want to with their amendments .. They are recommending that we should do that. There is delay, delay, delay and delay. What for? Because they are positioning themselves as some sort of allconquering heroes when they are not. Who could ever forget the promises they never kept? In 1993, they said that they would never increase taxes, yet they increased taxes by $10 billion in the last three years. Let us look at the amendments that the honourable member for Cunningham wants us to put forward. He challenges me and my colleagues to support his amendments. After looking through this book and after seeing the experience of my colleagues in this place, I wanted to know who has been a shopping centre manager. The honourable member for Forrest, Mr Geoff Prosser, is a shopping centre manager and so was 1. How many franchise owners are there in this place? I do not know of many, but certainly I was a franchise owner. How many corporate managers in this place looked after franchisees? I was one of them. I do not know how many on the other side there were. So there are quite a few examples of my experience in this field. The member for Cunningham talked about his experience. It came not only from an association with small business over a very long time but also from 'having a family tie in small business'. He said that most of his family members are involved in it in one way or the other, whatever that means. Perhaps they bought some soap or something; I do not know. What is he saying? He wants me to cross the floor and vote with him on amendments that I do not agree with because I have experience. I can say with some conviction that the principles of the fair trading report have been delivered by the Howard government into legislation. Let us go through the amendments that those opposite are talking about. The first amendment says: (l) is of the opinion that the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled 'Finding a balance: Towards fair trading in Australia' does not reflect the intent or recommendations of the Committee; That is absolute humbug. The intention and principles are clearly in the legislation. The second amendment states: (2) recommends the Bill be amended to incorporate the recommendations of the Committee; Where has the member for Cunningham been? Of course the principles are in place. The third amendment states: (3) considers the Government's response is inadequate and its rhetoric does not match either its election commitments or the committee's findings; What a piece of humbug to have the Labor Party even suggesting minutely that we do not meet our election commitments. Of course we do. When it comes to small business and any other business area, we do. Those opposite do not, and they never have. They let the small business community down for many years. That is why it does not vote for them, and that is why it will never vote for them. With these approaches, they try to get that vote. The fourth amendment calls on government members to cross the floor and support the recommendations. That is clearly not going to happen because the government members of the committee are very happy with this report. I am sure that the committee members from the other side who are speaking on this will support it. If they do not support my assertions on this, let them clearly articulate where they do not. I will look forward to their speeches. Mr Jenkins-You are ignoring the whole of chapter 6.
